description:
ordered grilled beef noodle soup and another dish which contains tomato soup

good taste and big portion
so great to sip hot water in a cold day
author: 以欢

description:
Don't get me wrong. Of all the food places on Irving, Loi's is probably one that I would choose because of it's authenticity. When I was first introduced to Loi's I thought it was heaven on earth because of how cheap the food was. You would get a big portion of pho for about $2 cheaper than the other places. The rice plates are very big too. For the last couple of days, I've had Loi's pho because I was sick at home and couldn't eat anything else. It's definitely all quantity here. 

But for me the problem is that it lacks quality. The few times that I went with my family and we shared some items family style, I noticed that the meals were just the same except with either rice or noodles. The 5 spice chicken we got was a bit too salty and it looked and tasted exactly the same in both dishes. The broth for the pho was the same as well. First couple of times I went, it was fine. But then as I tried other dishes on the menu, I noticed that it was the same type of broth all across. I suppose that's why they can serve that much cheaper.
author: Tom C.

description: Solid pho in a mom & pop setting , good spring rolls, 3 portion sizes , great prices, cash only. Full of vietnamese clientele , always a good sign.
author: Aaron Z.

description: Amazing food!!! Mr. Loi and Moma make the most authentic and delicious Vietnamese food in Northern California. The Shrimp spring rolls are unbelievably fresh! The Vietnamese Egg rolls are just delicious. All the Pho has flavorful broth and is super fresh with all the fixings. The barbecue meats are out of this world. Flavorful, thin cut, a crispy touch , but super tender. Try the pork chop, they are to die for. I am getting hungry to go again just writing about this great spot. It does get crowded, but what do you expect, it's so good! Mike McNair
author: Mike M.

description: The worst eating experience, the waiter is very rude. Because the price has changed, but the store has not change the price on the menu. We are totally understand that. But when we questioned, the owner misunderstood us and said " Are students could not afford that price?" And he kept abuses us!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Caveat: I didn't have any noodle soup, which seems to be where all the RAH spirit emanates.

For me, $10.15 price tag for a smaller than usual cup of Café Nong ( hot chicory Vietnamese coffee) and gross cha gio (egg rolls) : not worth it.

The glass was skinny pygmied, and the latter were not prepared well: skin not crisp, oil overhang, clinging to the thing. I was famished, too much aerobics and no real meal, so I did eat them.

If you come to Loi's, you gotta do what the Romans do, and stick with the soupy noodles. Bowls were on every other table in the small joint.

It may be worth noting that there is a very odd smell inside. I cannot place it, and I'm usually quite good with the nose!
author: Jana C.

description: This should be 2.5 stars.  Have not eat here for a long time and want to see if they have changed.  The price have risen like every thing else in the Sunset district but the quality have gone too.  I usually I love pho but I didn't finish the rice noodles nor the soup.  Several yrs.  ago, the soup was rich made with real meat, today it was bland and tasted like the leftover noodle cooking water.  There is also a pervailing plastic taste on the noodles and tea.  Some time it could be the noodle factory made a bad batch which I can understand or they have an off day.  I like family run business but I guess I will not be coming back.
author: Mar H.

description:
Come to Loi's for quantity and for cheap eats. 

For me, if I'm looking for Vietnamese food, I'll be honest, Loi's is not my first choice. There are a number of Vietnamese restaurants on Irving that, in my opinion, taste and present better. That being said, is Loi's probably one of the more authentic joints? Probably. Regardless, my parents were very intrigued by the consistently long lines that flood out of this restaurant so that's why we came - to satisfy their curiosities. 

Mom had the beef stew noodle soup which was probably the best of all our choices. The beef stew and tendons were tender and had excellent flavor. Dad opted for the "combo" charbroiled pork and noodle soup. The charbroiled pork was like little barbequed nuggets of pork. It didn't have that delicious charbroiled smokiness nor that sweet yet savory meaty bite to it. As for my Special Beef noodle soup, the thinly sliced steak looked like it was beat with a cleaver a million times until it became a roughly chopped patty. It did not look appealing at all. The broth was also a little too tepid for me.

We also opted to share a plate of the cha gio...lord...nothing could save these babies. They were severely over fried leaving a brittle/broken oily mess. Do yourself a favor and skip these.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
The food is authentic and the prices are ghetto cheap.  The female owner is super sweet, but her asshole half is a bully.  

He yelled at us for placing a mini sauce dishes into the noodle bowl for easy pickup.  Guess what, two can play the same game and we are the paying customer.  And homie don't play that... fired back at him with double barrels and braddah never knew what hit him.

Go for the food, but beware of the male owner.
author: Dennis Y.

description:
Small and straight forward pho spot for a quick order and eat experience. Don't expect frills or great service but do come knowing you will receive consistent Vietnamese noodle soup for a very affordable price. This family run hole in the wall restaurant has been around since I was a child and seems to be going strong! 

3.5 quality food rounded up to 4 stars for $
author: Carissa G.

description:
I heard about a family run Vietnamese restaurant on Irving St that was an inexpensive, no frills hole in a wall place.  The restaurant is small with about eight tables and most were occupied.  But today, I was here to take out.

The menu consists of pho noodle soup, pho bbq noodle soup, pho chicken noodle soup, bun bbq rice noodle and bbq rice plates.  I decided on #27 Com Bo Nuong - BBQ Beef over Rice for $6.25.  I added an egg roll for $1.50.  Within 10 minutes of my order, the food was up and ready.  At $6.25 for the entrée, it was a great value.  The food was good and the portion of bbq beef was quite large.  The egg roll was not crispy, but my order was a take out.  So it could have gotten a little soggy by the time I got home. 

The pho, buns and BBQ rice plates on the menu are very reasonable with nothing more than $8.25.  Great value for good Vietnamese food.
author: Al L.

description:
This is exactly the sort of hole in the wall place I love finding in SF, that I worry about, and that I hope never goes away. 

You can tell from first glance at the menu that it's probably great, cause it's crazy cheap and the English is terrible (this is usually a good sign!). Then you look inside at 1130AM and discover:
-it's full
-most of the clientele are Vietnamese, and many seem to have been coming here for years (and speak Vietnamese with the owners, an older Vietnamese couple)

Primed for excellence, I wasn't disappointed. I ordered the "Com Bo Heo Nuong" (BBQ pork and beef), and it arrived like 2 minutes later. The flavors were all amazing, the portions were generous, and the homemade spicy sauce served with it was delicious too. 

Man the prices are just amazing. And they include rice and tea too. And they're the same all day; it's even more of a deal at dinner. 

Curiously, I don't really like their jalapeño sauce on the table; it's kinda floral (this is the first time I've encountered this). But, everything else is great; not every last item has to be perfect. 

I also got five spice chicken (ga ngu vi huong) with cha gio to go. How could I not? Cheaper than feeding myself from the grocery. Likewise, it was outstanding. 

Next time I'll probably try the pho, bun rieu, and the cha son da (sounds like a viet version of a Thai iced tea)
author: Chris S.

description:
Metered parking in front. 

I put in enough money for 45 minutes at the meter, but was in and out of the restaurant in 20 minutes!

Came on a weekday around 1:20pm, the staff were quick and my #1 pho was served less than 5 minutes after I ordered. Pretty good pho, though the beef ball can taste a little off at times...

Very small restaurant. Everything will be sticky - the floors, chairs, and tables (I see the waittress wipe the table and chairs with the same dirty cloth), but guaranteed to satisfy your pho fix and get you in and out quickly.
author: Amy T.

description:
Years later, and now with a two year old in tow, I still love coming to Loi's. When you come here regularly, they treat you like family. 

I've discovered their Bun Rieu dish which is shrimp and crab in vermicelli noodle soup. It's so good and reminds me of my mom's bun rieu. They are really sweet to my two year old and have a high chair and booster. 

I have high expectations when it comes to Vietnamese food, mainly because my mom is an incredible cook. This place is amazing. The food is spot on and the prices are just right. It's our family's happy place.
author: Tina T.

description:
A simple place for delicious affordable Pho'. 
Working and on the run I really just wanted spring rolls both fresh and fried.. So I ordered Goi Cuon (fresh shrimp roll) which came with delicious bbq pork as well as shrimp, served with fish sauce (yum) and peanut sauce (meh). On the flip side Cha Gio, fried Vietnamese Egg rolls unless there was something lost in translation, they came fried with well seasoned meat, rice noodles, and a sparse amount of vegetables and also with fish sauce. Perfect. 
When I have time I will stop for Pho or a vermicelli plate but for a quickie bite this was nice.
Note: I tried to eat at the Thai place across the street with all the old accolades but I found it to be loaded with white people and lacking in service. 
"I f you find yourself in a Chinese restaurant and there's not a prevalence of Chinese eating there, run. "
author: Ezilu G.

description:
Is this the best Vietnamese I've ever had?  No.
Does it taste the closest to home-cooked comfort food?  YES!

I'm a bad Asian.  I'm actually so American that neither I nor my parents nor my parent's parents know any other language but English.  Geez.  So by that means, I fricking LOVE "white people" Asian food.  Which means I kinda like the umami/msg-rich beef and chicken broths of good pho.

Now I'm fortunate enough to get home-cooked, authentic, Vietnamese Pho meals every now and then from a close friend.  I don't like it as much as the restaurant versions.  Loi's feels much closer to the home-cooked stuff with just a little bit of added salt.  So I don't really dig it but I can see why people who really want a taste of home might.

That being said, Loi's has big portions for cheap prices. I'm not Vietnamese (heck, I'm barely Asian except for the colour of my skin), but I thought the Cha Gio (chai-ya, or eggrolls) were yummy and the fish sauce was good (what do I know?).  I thought the pho was good, but too "authentic" home cooked for me (kinda bland but salty).  The portions were huge, and the two dishes were under $13.00.  

It's a hole-in-the-wall that will keep you full on a budget. Just don't go to the bathroom.  There's a reason why hole-in-the-walls taste so good.
author: Kimiko Q.

description: What's the value of happiness? For some, it's a bunch of meat sitting on top of a hot bowl of noodle soup. For others, it's the cool sweet caffeinated draw of a refreshing authentic iced coffee. And for others, happiness is itself the value. Like a smiling face at the bottom of a bowl. You've not seen it? The smiling face at the bottom of the bowl of pho? Probably because the soup is left aside like some cheap sideshow act in this 3-act play. But if you tried to actually get to the bottom, one slurp at a time, your glasses fogging up from the still hot soup, you will see that smile at the bottom. And it will be on the reflection of the bowl.
author: John C.

description: really good viet rest the soup is 1 of the best at sf but is dirty is hell the owner is rude too 8 out of 10 if u eat there u will find your pho have small ant or small fly.
author: Mike T.

description: Bad attitude. My friends and I were trying to order food but the server was too busy having side conversations with other people to take our order. Mind you, she was standing in front of our table but her head was towards someone else that she was having the side convo with. We waited a good 5 mins for her to finish talking. The pho was good but the 5 spice chicken... tasted like it was just drenched in soy sauce, and not the 5spice/flavorful. The cashier screamed "you guys are stupid" in a really aggressive tone to me and my friends because we split the bill and gave him $27 instead of $25. If he is unhappy for dealing with giving people back change then he shouldn't be a cashier, or he should just kept quiet instead of screaming at a customer. The workers/servers doesn't deserve tips due to their lack of respect and poor attitude towards customers.
author: Xufei Z.

description:
Don't come here if you are expecting something that's sparkly clean. Floors and tables are grimy and the place has flies zipping around all over the place. I only come here because the pho is cheap, it gets the job done to satisfy my pho cravings, food comes fast, and also because it's very close to home. Ordered a number one medium (they don't have small sizes here). Pretty average tasting. 

Service is always awful every time I come in here. The guy never greets anyone when they walk through the door. He just gestures customers to a table. Doesn't say anything when he's taking your order.. Just looks at you and expects you to speak. Also doesn't say thank you or please or you're welcome. In the words of Stephanie Tanner, how rude! Oh and here's my favorite part. When I asked for a cup of cold water, the guy goes "no water! Only hot tea!" Alright then I guess.. Had to settle for tea. But I thought to myself, how do you make tea without water....?! Oh well. Didn't feel like arguing. Oh and this place is cash only. Save yourself the experience of poor customer service and only come here if Kevin's and PPQ down the block have a long wait and you need to satisfy your pho cravings.
author: Cynthia T.

description:
It's an SF-Irving-Sunset institution. My uncle use to take us here all the time ever since the early 90s. Now every time we go, we remember him, we remember the great dives in SF. 

The food is dirt cheap...literally . The pho's are tasty, bbq plates are seasoned deliciously and cooked to a tenderness, literally don't need teeth to chew. Lol
author: Aga O.

description: I've been coming here for the past 15+ years.  For the longest time it was one of the best deals around for Pho.  But times have caught up with them.  No longer a deal as they are now competitive with the rest of the Pho places on Irving St.  Unfortunately the quantity hasn't changed. Better places for Pho on Irving now at these new prices.
author: Acura Nsx T.

description:
Anthony Bourdain's recent dining experience with President Obama in Vietnam featured a dish called bun cha Ha Noi (aka North Vietnam BBQ pork with rice noodles in cold broth). Thanks to Yelp, we were able to find this dish at Loi's, a micro-famous hole-in-the-wall serving northern style Vietnamese food. And there's even a bit of Northerner attitude thrown in for fun, but don't let the loud waiter put down your spirits. The dish was excellent and I'm sure both Bourdain and Obama would agree. Another dish we tried was the "locals only" crab and shrimp paste noodle soup. The broth was aromatic and the use of minced chicken to hold the crab paste was perfect. We pair with the ubiquitous shrimp spring rolls. 
But the big kicker was desert, where we had a home-brewed Vietnamese iced-coffee. Definitely get the iced coffee for dessert! Wow that was so good!  I want one now.
author: Brian J.

description:
Loi's Vietnamese restaurant is my go-to Vietnamese food place in the sunset area. It is affordable and fast. They also take to-go orders, and it is ready pretty fast.

Interior-wise, it is crammed and not the cleanest. My favorite is the beef noodle soup #1 (medium size), come out to be $5.30 with tax. Beef is served in the soup kinda raw, so you can let it soak longer in the soup if you prefer more cooked meat. Typical soup base flavor, generous amount of basil and bean sprouts. 

I have also tried the Bun rieu, but was a little disappointed. The color is very red/ orange, so I was expecting a bunch of flavors, but it was quite blend. The rice noodles was also broken into tiny short pieces. Maybe I will stick with #1 beef pho in the future. 
 
Average hygiene, average service, slightly above average food, but really, nothing can beat the price!
author: Karen C.

description: I've been coming here for more than 5 years and even though this place isn't the cleanest of all, you'll get the most authentic Vietnamese Pho and Bun Cha you'll ever get. The owner doesn't speak that much English (which makes it even more authentic) but since I've been coming here for more than 5 years, the moment I step in this restaurant, the owner already knows what entree I will order and there's no need for me to tell him what I want. Food is served in less than 5 minutes with a complimentary tea. This place is also cash only so make sure you have enough cash to pay.
author: Ad R.

description: To make this simple. I like this place, we make it our spot on Thursday nights. It's good and its cheap. Two can have dinner for under $20. Love the tables, service is simple.
author: Brian W.

description:
10 out of 10 for the food! I order the BBQ chicken and Pork Pho, the meat was tender and seasoned nicely, plus the Price is very nice,(the cheapest Pho I've ever had in SF)
The reason why I am giving a 4 star instead of a 5 is because I think this place should be clean up a little bit. The table was kind of sticky for some reason.

All in all, I will definitely come back again!
author: Emily H.

description: Our whole extended families come here for a medium bowl of Pho'. It's almost habit that we drop by here for lunch after shopping on Irving. You can find many bad things about it if you look hard enough, like everything else. Based on price ratio quality, it's as good as it gets. A medium #1 just comforts me just right. Slices of rare beef, strings of beef tripe, slices of fatty pork log/roll all mixed in w/a clear broth along w/rice noodles in string or 1/4 inch flat form. Comes w/the usual plate of condiments of bean sprouts, lemon grass, jalapenos & limes. Still save myself enough room for dinner later on. For me the larger sizes are too overwhelming & is less enjoyable. Over stuffing oneself is not a healthy way to dine, or order the extra large to share & a side order of egg rolls. Their beef stew over rice is awesome too & lots of pieces of meat w/that half inch of fat hanging on it. Meat lovers know what I'm talking about & the sauce w/cuts of carrots & onions. Saves me a trip to the tenderloin or to San Jose. My Pho' fix is done for the moment. It's a family restaurant run by a couple & their relatives. Sometimes you see the snobs who walk in here cringing @ the décor & probably won't come back which means more for me & the fans of this restaurant later. If you're a worldly fan of street food, in any ethnic form, this is your place. A hidden treasure especially in SF's rising cost of eating out along w/everything else. Loi's is not likely to appear on PBS's "Check Please" w/Leslie Sibrocco. The whole world don't revolved around a bow tie, sometimes it's a pair of worn out brown shoes. Don't be shocked if you go there an hour before they close & they tell you they're out of broth. It has happen to us especially during cold nights which compliments just how good the Pho' is here. I'm due for a bowl right now.
author: Stevie C.

description: Not sure why Loi's doesnt have a higher review...but this mom and pop place is your classic pho restaurant with all the basics.  Its not fancy, its not half assed, its serves most of the dishes that i grew up with and it comes with love....by love i mean the service isnt the best and the place is a little dirty but whatever, its priced well and doesn't require a wait usually.
author: Vince L.

description:
My go to place for Vietnamese food that taste authentic and homemade. 

Food: 
I always get the Pho special and it definitely hits the spot each time. I like how the broth isn't salty and loaded with msg like other pho restaurants. It definitely taste like the chef spent time cooking the broth to perfection. The amount of noodles is perfect as well since they don't saturate the dish with just noodles but with other ingredients like tripe, tendon, beef, etc. 

Price/Service:
The service reflects its price. Don't expect 5 star service here but how many Asian places have 5 star service anyways? It is super cheap and cash only.

Overall: 
Will definitely stop by each time I'm in the area and craving Vietnamese food.
author: Annie V.

description: Loi's is the best place to go for cheap and good pho. The only recommendation I have is don't plan on the prices listed online being the prices in store. They only take cash so when I ordered ahead and only brought $20 (which based on online prices should have covered the 3 pho I was getting) it only covered 2. But the man working was nice and just gave me two and took the one back (didn't refuse service or make a huge fuss). I appreciated that, and made do with just the 2 soups. I 100% recommend the BBQ options or the seafood combination option (my two favorites).
author: Michelle B.

description: I've been here multiple times and this review is in no way dissing the restaurant, it's really to let customer know what to expect when coming here. People come to loi's because they are cheap and the food isn't bad and you can probably leave the restaurant full and spending under $10. In the city that's almost unheard of. The service isn't great and you kinda need to already know what you're going to order when sitting down because the waiter will immediately ask you what you want to order. Also, if you are lucky and wanted extra condiment, maybe just maybe the waiter will have time and get it for you. For some reason, I'm okay with the not so great service here, maybe it's because I have low  to no expectation when I come here. Remember to clean all Utensils and be careful when going to the restroom, the floor is super slippery.
author: Angela T.

description: This place has super cheap priced pho and other viet rice dishes. The quality is not bad but definitely very mediocre compared to other viet places. Would help if they cleaned up the store a little since the place looks kinda dirty and there are always flies flying around whenever I eat there.
author: Victoria T.

description:
Super authentic Northern Vietnamese comfort food. This place is run by a very efficient husband and wife team. Don't expect 5 star service and coddling. They get you fed in shortest time possible with a very authentic attitude. You kind of feel like you are in someone's home kitchen because the place is so small. Prices are some of the most affordable in this neighborhood, trade off for being cash only. 

We came after Hardly Strictly Bluegrass let out. There was a line out the door of every other restaurant on Irving that night but we chose this place because it had the shortest line and the line was actually moving as customers were getting served pretty fast. Glad we made the choice to pop in! The egg rolls and pho we ordered were delicious and everything came to around $22.00 with tip to feed two people. We were very satisfied. Definitely will be back.
author: Taryn S.

description:
Place has character. It was worth my meal and more to see Loi hustle out the restaurant and tell a group FU and never come back. Not sure what happened but it looks like the group ordered and left before the food arrived!

Anyway, food wise I don't think it's any different than PPQ or Kevin's noodle house which are consistently packed. It was almost half the price of the other pho spots and I had H which was the tomatoey shimp and crab based noodles. Interesting and tasty. Medium is plenty. 

I didn't think it was dirty. It is no frills.
author: Regina C.

description: Loi's Vietnamese Restaurant is a great place to get authentic Vietnamese Food at a very reasonable price. The Pho noodle soup is always consistent, and the rice plates always come with generous portions. Pieces average about 8$ per person without drinks. If you are going around Irving or other heavily populated streets, and can't seem to decide where to go, Loi's is a great place to try out!
author: Justin C.

description: Got yelled at for ordering 2 cups of water if we only gonna drink one. We only ordered ONE cup of water in the first place, but the worker, who took our order, was very nice and gave us 2 cups.. Also overheard the boss(?) talking in Cantonese about not serving water and only giving tea out. The guy with white button up and black vest was very rude. Pho was really good and this isn't my first time there.. but that guy made this time experience just speechless.. don't know if I want to go back if he's gonna yell at people for ordering water..it is the new year and he just ruined my day. Thanks
author: Angela Q.

description: Made my sister puke for around an hour, I'm not even kidding! Food is absolutely NOT CLEAN. Would you rather go somewhere cheap or somewhere that is clean and safe? I would not recommend this place to anyone
author: Celine C.

description:
BESTTTTTTT BESTTTT BESTTTT BUN CHA HA NOI EVER IN ANY RESTAURANTS IN SF OR NY. Sooo cheap in price but very tasty food. They don't take card so just bring cash when you go. Their pho are also tasty.
Try to avoid busy hour like lunch or dinner becaus it is tiny and no restroom :)
author: Thuy H.

description: What a pity!!!! I've been coming here for over 25 years  and loved it...we moved away and came back yesterday after only about a year.  The prices went up up and the quality went down.. we were overcharged because we got the egg rolls with the BBQ beef, the prices are right there but the owner insisted she was charging us the right price...she wasn't...we ordered 4 meals to go and all the beef in all the meals was over cooked, short of beef jerky ...what a disappointment ..Never again!!!
author: Gene K.

description:
This is actually my favorite pho place now. Cheap prices, delicious tasting meat, and food is usually consistent. 

I've learned that a medium bowl is good enough as long as we get egg rolls with our pho but I would get a large if we don't get the egg rolls. The egg rolls is really good and taste good with the peppers in the sauce containers. 

Overall, this is a great cheap and great tasting pho place that is now my go to place if I want something to eat in the Sunset.

Pros:
-Cheap and good tasting pho

Cons:
-Really small place and table can feel a little sticky
author: Paul U.

description: I really like their food here. It is really good every time I come here. They get the order right and it is really cheap. Like $6-7 for a bowl of PHO. I usually get the Beef Ball Pho. Closed on Wednesdays. They sell PHO, rice noodles, noodles soups, and etc.
author: Kelly T.

description: Highly Affordable, good Vietnamese fare that's been around for ages! Their beef accompanied with the pho is chopped style. I like to order mine on the side! Also the bbq meat pho is great too, and not something many other places carry! The portions were well sized! Limited amount of tables but food comes quick!
author: Tramy V.

description: Been coming to this restaurant since the mid-eighties. And they've always been reasonably priced and delicious. The staff treat you like family.
author: Miguel C.

description: Very small and dirty establishment. They always say the dirtiest and smallest hole in the wall is where the best food is really at. Their bun Rieu is only 5.25 for a medium! Unbeatable prices and great tasting. If you are looking for a cheap meal, this is definitely the place to go to.
author: Ada H.

description:
There's a right way and a wrong way to dine at Loi's.
Loi already has an idealized customer in mind, so any expectations you may have as a customer must be set aside in order to have anything resembling a pleasant dining experience.

1. You will need to be exactly a party of four, as the tables are not large enough to accommodate two sets of two as you will be a bit snuggled up to complete and total strangers. If you are a party of one and seated alone, you may be ejected from your table mid noodle slurp at any time, also be prepared to be insulted if you cannot comprehend their increasingly fervent demands to move.

2. Order immediately just after sitting down, not one second longer, as Loi's attention will quickly wan. 

3. Order either numbers 1 or 2, or possibly 3 if you feel particularly adventurous. Ordering beyond the number #5 is a dangerous game. Also know as "The Barnyard Raffle", ordering beyond these numbers means you could receive anything from pure, iron laden blood to raw egg from one brutally tortured chicken. (**The rest of the menu numbers are really just for show, only vaguely related to the dishes that they describe- for example, ordering a #33 could really net you a #17 or a #51 and these orders are irreversible as Loi's rage, stemming from deep seeded inadequacy, can easily be triggered** )

4. Do not ever request water or dessert. The complementary tea in a child's already dirty plastic cup will suffice. If you ask for anything more than that, as in what you would think would be normal "ordering", it is really like demanding these things from a war torn country.

5. Do not ever examine the contents of your broth or what could lurk below your shiny perfect noodles. Eat most everything completely and blindly in front of you, like a hungry person with a severe and possibly life threatening disease. Same for exploring the hygienic qualities of the table, chopsticks, napkins and immediate dining area. These items may or may not have been used for standard surgical procedures, childbirth and/or the strangling and dismembering of 
hundreds of pigs.

6. If you have any leftovers, do not ask for a doggie bag, though if this mistake is already made (And Loi always remembers), you will need to pay for the first edition, classic, state of the art paper container, featuring in cartoon bamboo font "Thank You", for the low, low price of 50 to 75 cents depending on how much Loi despises you and/or his day thus far.

7. If you successfully followed items numbered 1 to 6, Loi, although not expressing it verbally or anywhere on his face, will glide past the tables with a certain demented pep in his step and turn the Charlie Chaplin clock backwards several minutes instead of his usually preferred forwards.
author: Dan S.

description: Worst service ever! I'm never coming back here again. The grumpy old man (owner) has anger issues. I was listening to him yell at his kitchen staff in Vietnamese. I asked him for ice water and he says they don't offer it in a rude tone. I ordered the popular Bun Rieu and it was mediocre. Customers only like this place because of the price. The price is not worth the shit service.
author: Billy L.

description: no good 。。there are have flies in their foodswhen we told the boss，he answered us with bad words。。I hope to deal with this matter correctly。。So I think there food unsafety
author: Bryan H.

description: 2.5 stars.  Cheap pho - $5 for a "medium".  Watery broth.  They give you a plastic cup of tea but won't give you water.  I know there is a drought but that is ridiculous.  Very noisy because the plates & things are thrown around which causes a ruckus.  A hole in the wall so was hoping for better.
author: Kim S.

description:
This is my favorite pho place ever. The prices are cheap and the food is good. My family and I used to go to PPQ on 19th and Irving a lot, but the food can't beat Loi's. As many previous reviews have noted, this place isn't exactly super clean and the service is probably gonna be bad, but the delicious food makes up for it. This is one of my to-go spots whenever I'm back in San Francisco. My favorite dish is Bun Rieu (crab paste with vermicelli noodle). It's soooo flavorful. 

Pro tip: eat your pho with the pickled jalapeños that's on every table. SO GOOD.
author: Michelle D.

description: Super cheap $5.20 total for a small beef pho noodle soup, it tasted really homey, I don't think the put momosodium glutamate within the broth in which a lot of pho restaurant chains do, for the price this is a true delight!
author: Carina L.

description:
Good food, very cheap 
Bbq beef with vermicelli and egg roll is always my favorite.
don't expect any service here
author: Nini B.

description: Bun rieu all day!  This hole in the wall is definitely good for flavor and great portions.  The spring rolls and the bun body hue is on point too.  Just gotta try it out. Not the cleanest place in the world, but I wouldn't say it's dirty.  They just like to chop up stuff while you eat.
author: Jeffrey T.

description: Definitely a hole in the wall sort of place. Not the cleanest place but never been ill. Been coming here for over a decade. I always order the same thing. BBQ Beef with noodle soup. I love their BBQ meats. Don't know what they put in it but it's like crack cocaine. Not that I do crack or know what that's like but I hear......... you know what I mean... it's addictive. I don't know why more places don't offer a BBQ meat with pho dish. The two really go well together.
author: B i.

description:
This place has been around for as long as I can remember. Prices stay cheaper then any pho place I have been. Beef broth for the pho is hot and good. Beef is not your typical sliced beef, instead its more of a chopped beef (so if you are accustomed to ordering "beef on the side," I wouldn't do it because i think this beef should be cooked well done, plus they charge an extra 50 cents to do so, weird). Tables seems pretty clean, but the floors were wet and there was a smell in the restaurant. 

What we ordered:
XL beef pho ($6.50, can't get better then that) - not the best but can't complain. It may not be the beef I like but everything else makes up for it. This dish came out probably 3min after we ordered.

Five spice chicken with imperial rolls on vermicell ($7.50) - not my cup of tea and definitely a dumbed down version. Instead of a thigh fillet, they used a chicken leg quarter. Instead of juicy seared/grilled chicken with crispy skin, I am certain chicken was boiled to cook all the way through and basted with teriyaki sauce on a pan. Not recommended!

Overall, you can't beat the price if looking for a budget friendly meal but I will stick to the beef pho from now on if I come back.
author: Harrison C.

description: Wonderful hole in the wall! Been here like 50+ times tbh. Owned by a cute old family. Honestly this is my most favorite place for pho because of how fast the food gets to the table and the prices!! Recently, they had just raised up but a dollar on regular pho dishes (used to be 4.75 now 5.75) but still pretty cheap! I noticed they upgraded some dishes or maybe it was just what I ordered. Before, the Bun Rieu would just have crab and shrimp paste and some garnishes but now they added tomatoes to it! So I guess that's a plus! Definitely recommend.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Food is good here and VERY, VERY cheap, you can get a medium sized bowl of pho for $3.95 (before tax and TIP, if you really do want to tip the rude owner of the restaurant).

I've been here on different occasions and I always come here for the food, but the service just keeps getting worse and worse, and the funny thing is, it's the same guy that's being rude.

On one occasion not too long ago, my friend had tea poured all over him and his clothes, and not even an apology came out from the server. 

Most recent visit, I asked for change for my $20 bill and he was very rude about it.

Avoid this hole-in-the-wall unless you don't mind listening to the owner yell and bicker half the time. Very dirty and bathroom is all the way in the back; beyond the kitchen.
author: Sam K.

description: I love this place. But most people don't. The owner is kind of mean but the food is the best. I recommend u get C1 to C5.
author: Kaung N.

description:
Best bang for your buck. Great mom and pop store in Outer Sunset. 

The meat isn't high quality. The noodles aren't the best. Presentation isn't 5-star either. I think their cleanliness rating was an 83. Good service in a Vietnamese store, you're joking right?

I stumbled into this establishment with friend a few weeks back and have made two official visits here. The decorations are tacky and the place is a huge clutter mess. Everything about this location would make an OCD person go nuts.

However ... the pho is pretty damn good and worth your money! This place is relatively busy too, so you know it's a favorite among the locals. I ordered their #1 House Special (XL) and was stuffed full on both occasions. They seriously give you a lot for $6.50. The Shrimp Rolls were also not bad either. 

Until next time, Loi's Vietnamese Restaurant! If you can withstand the crappy interior and ignore their healthy safety score of 83, then check this place out!!
author: Chinsin S.

description: I just found some metal from a scouring pad in my pho and I feel all grossed out now, not knowing how many other pieces I could have eaten before I found this one. I have been a long time fan of loi's and I've always known how unsanitary it may be, but because the food was always consistent and good for the low cost of each item, I've never strayed. But I just can't right now.. I am saddened that I have to turn my back a bit until I get over this.. And maybe some day give them another chance.
author: Tiff C.

description: This is review for food and pricing- not facilities - very small restaurant- for quick eating - food is tasty , go for" bun cha ha noi" , pho is good too - unbelievable pricing - $5 /$6 for an order ! Just wonder how the owner make money.. it's been like that for more than 10 years ..
author: Monica T.

description:
I found this place awhile ago and saw that the pho was extremely cheap! Today, my friends came to SF for the weekend and I decided, why not try this.  

The pho was great.  What I DID NOT like was the rude server who constantly gave my friends and me attitude.  We asked for 4 waters, and he completely ignored us, so we thought maybe he didn't hear us.  So we asked again and he only gave us 1 cup of water that wasn't even filled to the top.  Really now? You can't give us 4 cups of water?

On top of the water situation, we asked to split the check 4 ways, which led to him storming off pissed off mumbling to his coworkers near him in another language, and  slamming silverware and plates into the dirty container.  

Place is dirty, small, but the pho is good.  You get what you pay for.  
I just didn't appreciate the attitude from the server. 

Would I come back? Maybe, but I wouldn't eat there, I would take it to go to be honest.
author: Rochelle A.

description:
My mom use to come here when she first immigrated here.  The old dirty, sticky chairs and tables have been in the restaurant ever since they first opened over TWENTY years ago.  I think it's time to get new tables guys....

Disregarding the old furniture, this is my favorite pho place to go when I'm craving. The pho is delicious especially for the price. 

The owner knows me as the dude who uses all his napkins and he occasionally gets pissed at me and let's me hear about it but nothing phases me.  I come here for the cheap food not the service.  Sometimes he would get into an argument with some other customers, which entertains me like no other.  Cheap food and a show. Awesome.

I recommend this place for people who can handle a rude owner and eating on sticky/dirty tables.

Ps: don't eat their pickled jalapeños on the side.  Last time I went there, it was developing mold. Gross...
author: Nelson C.

description:
Pho was edible but nothing special. I got the pho with chicken, ham and egg. I was envisioning a fried egg, over medium. What I got was paper thin shreds of scramble egg, almost like what you scrape off the bottom of pan when making scramble eggs. And I don't know what my ham really was, is there imitation ham?? I scooped all the "ham and eggs" out of my soup. The chicken was good but I did not appreciate that half of it was still stuck on bones and cartilage etc.

The BBQ pork roll was almost good... The wrap itself was just too thin and mushy.

My water had some sort of film on the top so I didn't drink it. 

Cleanliness worried me a bit after reading other yelp reviews. They're definitely not very clean/sanitary here. When our waitress was clearing our table I noticed her hands were dirtied with some sort of black crap and stuck with a thick piece if hair. She wiped those hands with the table used for cleaning the table. Gross
author: Pauline T.

description: Loi's pho beats all others. Don't expect much service, just awesome and very affordable food!
author: Xuan Hong L.

description:
My happy little cozy place. 
Sticky tables but fast service and good Vietnamese variety of dishes! 

Favorites:
Bun rieu (crab paste noodle soup),
pho,
eggrolls,
spring rolls
author: Veranna N.

description:
Really good Vietamese food.

Really small but worth the cramp space.

Do not bring a big group with you.

Eat with a max of 4 people.

Parking will be tough.

Order, Eat, Pay - don't sit and talk for a long time, this ain't that kind of place.

Keep it quick and you'll have a great time.
author: Michael C.

description:
Got Vermicelli (Bún) with BBQ Beef and egg rolls. The meat was cold as if it was sitting out for hours. Could be someone ordered it by mistake and they just kept it in the back as our food came out within 5 minutes. The egg rolls were warm though. 

This was the first time I've had cold meat on my Bún in my lifetime so I thought I would ask kindly "is the meat supposed to be cold?". I get this 'I can't speak English' answer "cold noodle" "cold yes" and this really rude man (the only man working there) comes over and screams at us (we couldn't understand what he said). Afterwards the man would scream and throw plates REALLY HARD in the bucket behind me so the food would go on me. I didn't know what to do so I stayed calm. The thing is, they sat us at a larger table and then a party of four came in and they asked us to move to a very small table in the back near their food bucket. 

My friend didn't eat his meat but I did. It was the worst Bún we've ever had. This place is really dirty too. NOT recommended. They got a low health score as well. I hope they get shut down.
author: Giordano G.

description: The pho isn't spectacular but for $5 a bowl, it's totally worth it. The older man seems a bit grumpy at first but he's actually quite funny if you get to know him.
author: Susanna K.

description:
We've walked by this place a couple of times a week on our way to the 22nd/Irving market, but never stopped in until yesterday.  After our experience, it is unlikely that we would eat here again.  

We arrived about 1145 hours and the place was packed.  Luckily, someone was just leaving and we occupied the table.  By 1215, the restaurant had emptied out. It looks like a mom and pop type restaurant and the pop came by to clean our table.  He piled everything into a soup bowl and made kind of a mess while cleaning up.  The table was sticky and the wooden chairs were not comfortable.  Somehow the seat is not very wide and it pressed against the back of our thighs.

The pop took our order and seemed a little "POed".  Judging by the other reviews, it is his normal character.  Plastic cups of thin tea were brought out.  I had an extra large bowl of Loi's special beef pho while the other party had had some vermicelli with five spice chicken.  I can't remember the price of either item, but the total bill was about $14.  The prices are about 10% or so less than other Vietnamese restaurants such as PPQ down the street and there are reasons why.  

The soup came first and even though it is advertised as extra large, it is no bigger than a competitor's "large".  Nothing special about this soup, though their were large pieces of beef that could have been cut to bite size pieces.  Pho tastes the same and the broth is so-so.  The vermicelli dish came a few minutes later and consisted of a side of vermicelli and a chopped up, whole leg chicken.  It is unlike other restaurants and a knife and fork is needed to eat it.  The sauce was too sweet and the chicken flavoring was unusual and not really that appetizing.  Not many veggies were included.

I had my back to the kitchen, but could hear lots of yelling and the sound of loud banging and slamming of the plastic dishes.  It was a man's voice and probably that of pop.  The banging and yelling was unnecessary.  It is though the staff did not care that this noise might disturb the patron's eating experience.

The restaurant is not very kempt and by the health score, I can see why.  The service is very minimal and we had to ask for the check.  Loi's need to bring themselves to modernize and clean up their act and maybe they'll get as much business as PPQ.  If it involves raising prices, then let it be.  The way it is now configured, I would not want to eat here again.
author: Robert J.

description:
Cheap pho! Like $5 for a bowl! 

I got the pho tai and it was pretty satisfying on a foggy day. This place isn't the cleanest and the pho wasn't great but it was a good value. I also like how the place is owned by an old Asian couple who know how to cook. They spoke Cantonese so there is a little Canto spin on the pho seasoning which I actually prefer.
author: Steven V.

description: No complaints other than the place being very small. Often packed cause there aren't many tables and due to the fact the pho's so cheap. Get take out and avoid the wait when possible.
author: Liz N.

description:
Cheap, efficient, satisfying.

- The place is a bit dirty, but it is expected for a hole in the wall. Seating is a bit close together, very homely. 

- The food is above average for its price. The cut of meat is different from others, but it still goes well with the noodles. The noodles are cooked perfectly, not too hard, not too soft. The soup is as authentic as you can get. Doesnt taste like a blast of msg salt
author: Jake J.

description:
The food is undeniably cheap but the service, quality of the food and cleanliness of the place is not worth coming. The chicken and beef pho broth  we got were very plain and tasteless. The fried rolls we got tasted like leftovers, they were lukewarm and not crispy at all. To get to the bathroom you have to walk through the tiny kitchen to get too.

Overall, an unpleasant experience
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I've been coming to this restaurant ever since they first opened this restaurant on Irving 23-25 years ago.  It was the first Vietnamese restaurant in the area at the time, so we jumped on the chance to eat there as soon as they opened their doors.  It's the same decorations, tables, seats, and the Charlie Chaplin clock on the wall that would totally entrance me as a kid with its swinging legs.  Its menu hasn't changed, service is still the same, and owned by the same family all these years.  I still come in and get the same order I've gotten since childhood - Medium #5 (beef and fish ball pho).  

Sure it's not the cleanest place and it's dark in there, but it's the quintessential neighborhood dive restaurant that has survived on Irving all these years.  Every few years, new restaurants and chains (ohmygod like 3 boba places on one block, and boba places every which way you look) pop up on Irving, but over time, many of these stores close and a new business moves in.  Loi's has endured on Irving, and I hope it does for another 50 years!  I've moved away from SF and lived in various states in the last decade...everytime I come back to Irving, I'm always appalled and saddened by how much change occurs on this street; however, I can always count on Loi's for its food.  It's not gourmet in anyway, but it's reliable, cheap, and decent.

Overall, prices are dirt cheap, food comes out fast, portions are big, and you come out with a full belly.  What more can you ask for in a meal that can be under $5?  For those who complain about the service, you really just have to get to know the proprietors.  If you've eaten there enough, you'll get to know them and find that they're really nice people.  So ultimately, Loi's is an institution on Irving, and it has definitely been around longer and is older than so many of these little teenyboppers who wander around with boba cups ensconced in their hands.  

Man, this review makes me feel old...
author: Viva C.

description:
December 2013

You known that saying? "You get what you pay for?" Well that's the mantra you should have when you walk in here.

Don't expect them to greet you, or refill your tea, or kiss your ass.

And don't expect fancy tablecloth, nice silverware, or sparkly clean floors.

This is a hole in the wall place. Roach coach, without the coach.

But, I love their Cambodian seafood noodle soup and egg rolls. The noodles are generally less than $6.00, and it's a pretty good sized bowl of pho.

I've also had their BBQ beef. My second favorite thing to order here.

Just remember folks, they might yell, it's not a "clean" place, so if you're requiring that, then this is not your place.

Bring your own antibacterial and enjoy.
author: Jack R.

description:
$5.20 gets you a huge, hot, steaming bowl of deliciousness. 

I've been to a number of places in SF, in search of cheap, Seattle-priced pho and after years of searching, I've finally found it. The service is efficient, and straight-to-the-point, and fast. It's not fancy or anything, but it's tasty and quick and plentiful.

I've been back a few times since and I'll be returning soon again.

Bring cash - you'll be happy you did!
author: Katie A.

description: First time here and I should have walked back out, but I  gave them the benefit of the doubt. It was pure nasty and I do not know how to describe my experience
author: Sea R.

description: 鸡腿面粉。really hole in the wall. Good food at reasonable prices. Owners are ethnic Chinese
author: Will L.

description:
Loi's is small hole in the wall eatery. with 10ish tables. pricing looked cheap. not much decor, just some faded pics on walls..

eats: #1beef combo pho (lg.4.75)
-looked like a medium
-a beef ball, lots of beef strips, random tripe, tendon, etc. no kitchen sink
-broth beefy, sweet taste. probably slight msg added.
-noodles not al dente, kind of chewy, coarse.
-food came out fast.

leftovers:
-not the usual pho offerings, just meatball, beef combo, ....
-service just taking order, giving tea,....
-4 stars for cheap, 
-seating not so comfy, fan under table blocked leg movement
-sweet ladies but very busy.
author: Victor G.

description: long time standing - mom and pop vietnamese restaurant. They are loud but friendly. It's a hole in the wall but food is great and authentic and CHEAP!
author: amanda t.

description:
Firstly, I just have to say...I am SO GLAD I did not read some of the yelp reviews on the cleanliness of this joint before I came here.  And doubtful patrons, keep an open mind...it's a hole in the wall, what else do you expect?

All in all, I can say I thoroughly enjoyed my $5 bun rieu in peace and oblivion.  Stray cat hairs, dangling nose hairs, and dandruff on the side though, please.

Total items: 1 xlarge bun rieu, 1 medium bun rieu
Total damage: $11
author: Bernice C.

description:
Atrocious. Just... sooooo infuriatingly bad.

Where do I begin? I saw the decently good reviews, the shockingly low prices, the full house. We popped in and were seated at a very sticky table. We were having a hard time deciding since the menus were not in the least descriptive (special noodle soup.. what makes it different from the noodle soup?), and the waitstaff had no interest in helping. They just kept walking away with annoyance.

We ended up ordering a few phos and the dry seafood noodle. The waiter brought the pho over and his fingers were alllllll up in my soup, and they had visible grime all over them. The dry noodle was literally dry, and it's supposed to come with this sauce. When asked, the waitress YELLED at us that it's in there, just mix it. It wasn't, and we didn't pay for a clump of tasteless noodles. When we asked another waiter, we were again yelled at, by both waiters, in a combination of Vietnamese and Cantonese. They couldn't speak either very well, and certainly not English. Finally they just slammed some soy sauce on our table and walked away. Then my cousin found a bug in his pho. The pho was bland with very little meat, even though it was a big bowl of noodles and soup.

While we were sitting there waiting for someone to go get cash (there was no sign anywhere, not even on the menu that it was cash-only), people walked in and were told they were out of soup. How does a pho place run out of soup? The patrons were bummed but I wanted to tell them, "RUN, RUN AS FAR AND AS FAST AS YOU CAN."
author: Vivian H.

description:
I only came here for the second time recently with my friends. ALL my friends rave about this place and I really just didn't get it.

literally a whole in the wall and in terms of cleanliness, it kinda isn't. cramped up into this small place, I was ready to try Loi's pho a second time.  The first time was in high school (too many years ago) so I don't recall anything much. you know when you're in high school and there's cheap food and you just don't really care. and you probably think everything is good for less than 5 bucks!! hahaha

for less than $5, a medium bowl of pho to fulfill your cravings!  i went with the number 1 "special" and people might think... what is the special..??  they top the pho off with their "special" tenderized meat!  

pho special - price. on point. noodles. wow medium got me full! and broth.... yum!  their broth is so flavorful and not bland at all. I didn't expect much from the meat either, but surprisingly tender and delicious. they do not skimp on any of their ingredients!  my only ??! would be the meat on the side is $.50 extra which I kinda don't get... but it's whatever, the meat on top of the noodles come out rare and not drenched in soup already, so save your 50 cents for 15 minutes of parking meter. 

service - heard its hit or miss... sometimes the owner can be an angel and sometimes you'll just hear a lot of yelling in the background... but pho-wise, found another spot!
author: Josie L.

description:
Loi's is one of the few sit-down restaurants with prices that can give McDonald's a run for its money. Their medium Meatball Pho costs $3.99. You can get away with murder for $5 here at Loi's.

To fully appreciate Loi's bargain prices, we can see how far $3.99 will take you in other restaurants.

Mickey D's : The equivalent of a Filet O Fish.

Safeway Deli: Half a pre-made sandwich and some chump change.

Purple Kow: That caramel pudding milk tea. 

Other Pho Places: A slap on the hand for not paying your full bill.

Sure, the place is not the cleanest and the owner is not the most polite. But dude, you're paying $3.99 for a meal. Yes, MEAL. Just don't bring a girl you're trying to impress. But if you guys have been dating for around 4 weeks, then maybe it's nice to usher her here to stop your wallet's bleeding ; )
author: Ringo M.

description: The price is cheap for the amount of food they give. The pho and rice plates are not to bad. The male waiters needs to chill they seem angry every time I go there, the lady is alot nicer. Not going there for the service but for the food. Not a bad place to go if u want alot of food for the price.
author: Steven J.

description:
Love this place! This would be my number 1 'hole in the wall' restaurant if I were to recommend a place to eat.
Food is always good and on point. Also not to mention, prices are excellent too as you can get a big bowl of pho for under 6 bucks.
I tell my friends prices so low you can effort to tip more!
+ great food for its price
+ located in the busy Irving street
+ quick service
- tea refills can take a while when it gets busy
- not really the cleanest but heck it's a hole in a wall so not really a con...

Ps. Always order your meal with a side of spring rolls and if you are feeling lucky, a fried egg for rice plates 

11/10 will come back again for them to take my money
author: Jason L.

description:
Having come here since the early 2000's, its nice to see that not every single place i ventured into when i was younger was razed and re-designed to fit the over-hyped boba trend that had been taking place over the last 5 years. Even more so was i surprised that the prices here still haven't changed either.

The serving sizes haven't been skimped on, the broth isn't made of cheap stock.
I think i'm 90% certain, that the only thing new is the clock.
The waitress speaks multiple asian dialects including vietnamese including english so thats not a problem. The Menu leaves little to the imagination as everything is served as listed.

Oh and for those wondering about prices. The bowl pictured below costs less than 7$..and its XL size.....7 dollars usually gets you maybe a medium that comes in a small bowl at other places if you're lucky, but how many of these places allow you to modify which types of meat are in the soup WITHOUT:
A) messing up your order?
B)Charging you for sharing?
C)Putting their thumb into your bowl as they give it to you?
D)Understanding what it means not to rush the customer out?

How many of the places including Pho Hiep/Kevins are not run and/or cook their foods at the discretion of a non native asian?...

If you're too paranoid to carry cash, you're better of passing...
Come here for sure if you're too broke to have a credit card..
You won't need to worry about card scamming.

Because of SF rent rates and other things, the biggest issue with this place is that when its busy, it can get cramped..like elbow to door cramped.
author: Eric C.

description:
Still a 5-star establishment. I've come here for 7 years and the noodles have always been consistently tasty. I finally tried the pho, and it is amazing. It's very homestyle and doesn't taste anything like the pho broth in other restaurants that use flavor cubes to make their broth. If you've ever made pho at home, Loi's tastes as close to homemade as you can get. They don't give you a ton of broth, just enough to barely cover the top of the meat on the pho, which is another signal to me that they don't want to waste their own broth either. 

This place is the ultimate noodle shop. I hate going to other places for pho because they're always worse and always more expensive for no reason. Loi's continues to be the best hole-in-the-wall noodle place in SF.
author: Sofia N.

description:
I still can't believe how cheap the food here is! They do not skimp on the portions either, a medium size is able to fill up me and my boyfriend and it is under $5! 
Granted, the service isn't exactly the greatest but with such low prices and big portions, I am not complaining. The restaurant is pretty small and there is usually a little wait to be seated. My boyfriend sometimes sees one of the owners buying ingredients from the supermarket across the street, so you know you're eating something like a home cooked meal! 

I usually get the cambodian seafood here. I love the broth and the toppings, it's different from most pho places. The fried egg rolls and the spring rolls are also delicious and cheap as well. 

So, if you're looking for a meal that'll be under $10 for two people, you've found the right place! 

Don't forget, it's CASH ONLY!
author: Audrey C.

description:
My friend and I stopped by this place for lunch because the weather was gloomy enough for pho and because another friend had told me that he considers this place better than Turtle Tower.

The place itself is small (to the max), dingy, dirty looking--completely hole-in-the-wall family business. It kind of startled me a little bit. This place was not made to impress, it was made to feed.

I ordered a medium special beef pho while my friend ordered chicken and beef pho. We also ordered spring rolls to share. I was wary about this place because I read such mixed reviews, but the food I got wasn't so bad. 

I'm pretty picky with spring rolls but the ones here weren't bad. Very homemade. large portion, came with two sauces...twas pretty good.

The pho wasn't bad either. It tasted good in that homey kind of way which made it more comforting than other pho places. I didn't have anything to complain about my pho, but my friend was annoyed with his. He was given chicken pho instead of chicken and beef (which he got over) but then his chicken pho had a lot of bones in it. 

Overall, the food is pretty good. If you want some cheap, comforting, Vietnamese food then this place is a good choice but I am rating down because the overall cleanliness and impression of the place was not to my taste. I think if I went there again, I would still be scared about my food.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Probably the best cheap Pho you can get in this area. 

I always come here on a cold SF winter with the hubs, and go for the $5 bowl of large beef pho (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/znL7LepCC5iSWJRJ5JJlvg/l.jpg) and $4 medium chicken pho (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/BIFnDdysFpwnfT1oz2znMQ/l.jpg). It's too bad that they don't have any vegetarian summer rolls, so we resorted to ordering the pork skin roll (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lois-vietnamese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=ehzyC-XZHM2ZdYfmfC5dDg#ehzyC-XZHM2ZdYfmfC5dDg). 

We love the Phos, but not so much the pork skin roll..
author: Ximeng W.

description: This hole-in-the-wall family shop is SO DIRTY. But it's also SO CHEAP. 3/5 stars because it's dirty, but the price makes up for it. The food is also pretty tasty for the low prices, but it could because a little extra dirt was rubbed into it. I guess no one will ever know why the food tastes so good for the low prices, but nothing can beat a cheap bowl of pho.
author: Courtney D.

description:
Extremely rude, ridiculously unsanitary, disgusting pho. I'm used to hole-in-the-wall and rude Asian places--but the prices and food usually make me overlook that. Not this place. The old geezer guy (maybe the owner) sitting in the back is constantly yelling about something and there always seems to be an argument/fight going on in the kitchen. Flies are everywhere. Tables are worn out and sticky.

Pho wasn't anything special. The beansprouts they give you are the crappy ends that usually get thrown away. The prices ain't cheap enough for me to tolerate the crappy environment here. ($5.50 for medium + tax + tip totals to around $7).

I asked for the check and the old geezer just yelled the number out at me in some really broken Chinese. He stood there hovering as I went through my wallet to pay him. That struck a nerve, so I just let him stand there until his knees gave out. That's ok. I have all the time in the world. He got frustrated and murmured something and finally walked away. You run a restaurant--don't you have something else to do besides hovering around customers waiting for them to pay?
author: Cheri S.

description: I love places like this because Loi keeps it real. His lack of service and restaurant ambiance allow me to focus the quality of the food and the pho here is consistently a solid good. I also appreciate the diversity and cultural authenticity this little hole in the wall has maintained from our every other hipster coffee shop and pop-up around the corner in the city.
author: J B.

description: Maybe I'm biased living in the South Bay and having a high concentration of excellent Vietnamese food, but this place was awful. Spring rolls had a weird aftertaste, like freezer burn. 1 of the 5 shrimp on my plate was cold, meaning they cooked it earlier (leftovers from someone's plate? ) Place was way grimy (grimy even for hole in the wall Vietnamese). How did they ever get an 89 health score is crazy. Also, they forgot my fried egg and they don't serve ice water, only hot tea. WTF
author: Matthew T.

description: Pho in my belly makes me happy!  Whenever we're in the Avenues, we try to swing a meal at Loi's.  It is our favorite pho joint, even though it's kinda dirty, even though the wait is sometimes longer than I'd like, even though their egg rolls (cha gio) are mediocre, even though they don't have serve tripe (sach) with any of their pho, even though service is sometimes bordering on rude, because they tenderize their beef, because their soup has depth and flavor, and because their prices are dirt cheap.
author: Christina L.

description:
My girlfriend and I wanted to try something new and tasty and remember passing by some interesting pho restaurants on Irving.  We figured we'd give one a go and then grab some boba next door afterward.  Turns out, it became a great discovery!

I ordered the extra large bowl of pho for less than $6 (they have a $4 and $5 option too) and it was nearly too much for me to handle.  The soup wasn't perfect but totally acceptable for the price.  They've got a huge menu though so finding something for your taste isn't difficult.  I'm excited to go back for seconds and then some tasty boba afterward.

It's been tough finding a great pho restaurant since moving back to the Bay Area but I think I've finally found something to tide me over.  The smallest bowl is still huge and a total bargain.  No wonder they're always packed and seeing as though SF is always freezing, this is the perfect place for a quick meal.  I'll give the bun or rice a try next time!

Food: 7/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 6/10
author: Joe M.

description: If I could have given negative stars, trust me, I would have.  This place has the worst Vietnamese food ever.  I mean, I would have rather gone to Pho Kim Long in San Jose where the waitresses don't wash their hands after they use the bathroom (see my yelp review) than this place.  Five spice chicken was soooo tough and tasted more like soy sauce chicken.
author: C L.

description:
Recently tried this place with a friend who highly recommended this.  With the description of BBQ Pho, who was I to turn down something so different from what I was used to.

Crawling into this small restaurant with limited seating and high in humidity, we waited very little to grab a seat. Cash is king here but there are so many different banks on this street, you shouldn't have to worry about this right?

I ordered the BBQ shrimp and BBQ chicken Pho. Three different cuts of chicken and about 5-6 shrimp; this reasonably priced bowl of soup was well worth the stop after a "long" day at the park shooting things at a close-ranged target. The BBQ sauce seemed a little sweet with hints of hoisin, but honestly we just guessed because who knows? It tastes good. That's all that matters. Will I stop by again? If I want a change from my normal raw meat in hot soup, this will be the place to go.
author: Eric L.

description:
I love Loi's with a passion; every time my family and I decide to go out of our way for pho and Vietnamese food, this little hole in the wall is our first choice.

The pho - any dish, for that matter - is unbelievably cheap. Like my sister Christine M. says, you WOULD think that you would be getting something dirty or gross.

Quite the contrary. 

Best pho broth out there, and one of the best I've had in the Bay Area yet. Their pho ($3.95 - $7.25), rice noodle dishes ($4.75 - $5.75), and rice dishes ($4.95 - $6.95) are made to perfection; oily, a little greasy, and impossibly comforting on a cold, winter's night. If you're a fan of fish sauce - and you better be if you like Vietnamese food - you should definitely order the bun cha ha noi ($5.75), a North Vietnamese dish of BBQ pork, rice noodles, and a fish-sauce broth. 

Just wipe your utensils down before use, say a "Cám on!" or two to your kind server, and, well, dig in!
author: Colleen M.

description:
#1 Large...it was ok..didn't have as much meat as I would expect, but I suppose it's cheap. The veggies weren't fresh, but eh, what can you say for the price right? 

Free hot tea, small place..mom and pop place..runned by Chinese..so it's not REAL Viet pho. 

I definitely had better, the meat wasn't cooked all the way through bc the broth wasn't hot enough. The broth was sweet..odd..almost like a coconut taste to it..so I had to put the cock sauce and the hoisin sauce to make it better..

Not sure if I'd come back though..
author: Minerva L.

description:
If you're the type of person who has high expectations in terms of cleanliness, service, and quality of food... this is NOT the place for you. (You have been warned.) 

Loi's is the definition of a "hole in the wall". The service is meh, the decor needs to be updated, the menus... needs to be redone, sometimes the busboy forgets to wipe down your table, and the floor needs to be swept. If you can look past all this, then you're in luck. For starters, this place is as cheap as it can get for vietnamese food! $5 for a medium sized bowl of pho, $5 for spring rolls, $7-$8 for a rice plate.. you can't complain. 
I usually come here for the pho. The rice plates is a hit or miss. Sometimes the meat is burnt or sometimes it is a bit undercooked. Not to mention, the rice plates takes longer to make. By the time your friends finish their pho, your rice plate is still in the works. As for the pho, what is there to say? You have your rice noodles, soup, and your meat, along with a side of bean sprouts, mint, and lime. 

So why the 4 stars? Despite the flaws, the food is pretty good! I've been coming to this restaurant for 8 years and it is pretty consistent. I wouldn't say it is the best pho in the city, but it definitely hits the spot. You can't beat the fact that you pay less for the amount you get. And plus, I always leave here with a full stomach. 

Tip: Bring Cash.
author: Emily L.

description:
Hole in the wall Vietnamese Restaurant on Irving Street. Small place with less than ten tables. Easily forgotten because it is so easy to walk past the front door. I hadn't gone to this place for years. Then I realized, OMG, their price is so cheap. 

Loi's Special Beef Noodle Soup 
Medium $3.95
Large $4.75
XL 5.75

Pretty standard pho with meat. No complaints and no surprises. I need to go more often so I don't forget about this place.
author: Janice T.

description: Crazy cheap. Total hole in the wall. The #26 pork, tea, and #1 pho (no noodles) were really delicious. I would go back in a hot minute.
author: Andrew K.

description: If i can give ZERO i will!!! Rude customer service!!! Effin waiter!!! Or whoever!!!! Dont ever come here!!!!!
author: Jay-r M.

description:
I like to give small businesses a chance but the old man in place has such a bad attitude, he threw out my food after i asked him to save it.  I feel sorry for the people that run the place.  they just need to pack it up.

the place is filthy and everything is covered in grease.
author: User N.

description:
First time here was in 2002 roughly.

Pho comes in large portions at decent price. Noticed a few people don't like the service here... but here's a tip: the key to disarming this guy is to SMILE and say THANK YOU really loud. This usually gets him all confused and his normal "frown" straightens out. 

This place does not cheap out on the beef. Be sure to stir it, so the beef cooks slowly in the pho. Also, don't expect to be able to sit long. The lady boss brought out the check right on schedule.

The guy is not friendly. It's not personal. That's who he is. If he forgot something it's probably because he is old. Don't be afraid to speak up, repeat request if needed... take it easy, it's not the end of the world.
author: Bunny C.

description:
I wanted to give this place a chance because I heard good things about this place. When a friend and I walked in, they placed us at the table closest to the kitchen. You'd think that if you were closest to the kitchen you'd get your food slighty faster. Although that may be true, you also get the curse upon you if you were to say sit with your back towards the kitchen. That's where they happen to put the bins of wet and dirty dishes. I sat in that seat and I probably had some dish water splashed onto the back of my clothes. The food was average to me. The service sucks. When I wanted to tell the waiter to not put any green onions in my soup, he just walked away in a hurry. 

I would never come back here.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
Loved their $6.5 special beef pho. Even though it's a small place and the line is always long, they totally worth it. 
But don't expect to too much for customer service.
author: Edward L.

description:
The last thing I will do is to pay for a cranky old man to serve my lunch. The server - this man was extremely rude to me and my 4 year old and yelled at my son when he was playing at the table. 
When asked if I could add vegetables to my order he angrily said NO! So I said: "It's alright, we'll just go somewhere else." He then angrily took away the spoon that my son was holding then took away our water in a storm. I'm sure that if he had kids he abused the hell out of them.

No person should be treated this way and I'm glad I didn't support such an establishment! I would've given NO star if I could (or negative stars)!
author: Sway M.

description:
As other reviews stated, this place has bad customer service, but you can't really expect much from low-price, cheap asian restaurant... Do not expect timely greeting and seating. Just seat yourself. 

Waiter was having a bad day? He yelled at me and my date for asking for 2 cups of water... 

Food wasn't that great. Bunbo huay tastes like tomato soup.. Pho was too beefy..might have just been the bad service that turned me off to the food...

It was cheap. Probably would never go back. You can do better!!
author: Vickie W.

description:
This place is A MESS! Me and my friend went there today because we were starving and that was the closest restaurant we could find that was open. 
The seating was surprisingly narrow and tiny, floor was dirty. We still decided to stay because it was hard to find parking. 
The waiter didn't even greet us or arrange us to sit, instead, he went straight to us to ask us what we wanted.
He didn't really speak English but I thought he would at least get my order right. But no, he gave me the wrong noodle soup. I asked him if it was possible for him to double check my order and he got REALLY RELLY MAD. 
He refused to exchange me the right thing and all of the sudden he started yelling at me. I was shocked by this extremely bad customer service and had no clue how could this restaurant keeping its business running if they don't even care about their customers. 
And of course I had no idea about how their food was since I didn't even get a chance to even taste it.
I was hoping for an option to rate them zero star for the terrible customer services.
author: Shirley X.

description:
Even though there was a hair in my soup, I still ate it. 
Even though I had to wait for the cook to finish filling her pot before crossing the 7'x7' kitchen to get to the bathroom, I'd still come back. 
Even though I had to pee in the dark because the naked bulb in the 3'x3' bathroom was out, I'd still come back. 

The broth is that good. Not salty and flavorful. Plus a medium pho for $4.75 is perfect. 

(But I'm very aware that I need higher standards.)
author: Jenna Rose F.

description: Cheap and delicious! Cleanliness isn't too great but as expected for a hole in the wall. I usually get their pho as I like their chopped beef or the bun cha ha noi which you don't see too often. Their egg rolls are damn good compared to other restaurants. Didn't care too much for their bun rieu though.
author: Richard T.

description: Reasonable price , The owner is nice if you know them . Maybe for 1st time seems rude . The best pho is beef pho . On the menu is no.1  , BBQ pork and Beef stew . No other Vietnamese Restaurant in Bay Area could beat the taste Loi's BBQ pork and Beef stew . It's very recommended .
author: tang c.

description:
I only came once since a fan of this place took us here. We had the Loi's special and bbq shrimp and beef rice. It was absolutely delicious. The price was not bad either. Combined with the portion of the food, this place is definitely worth it. 

A plus is the boss was funny and helpful to customers who needed coins for parking. I'd definitely come back again if I'm ever in town!

The egg rolls they offered were delicious as well! 

Cons is that they don't look that clean, but I have yet to complain about a stomach ache. The only pain I get is from an overfull tummy!
author: Amy T.

description:
I couldn't imagine good bun rieu exists in the Sunset, but it does! Located on the busy strip on Irving, Loi's has seriously such a small storefront that you probably could miss it if you didn't pay attention. Inside, the restaurant literally has eight tables, some larger than others, and on a busy day, you may be asked to share a table if you're dining by yourself. 

To me, all these things, including bad customer service, don't matter. I'm there for the food and I was in a serious need of a bun rieu fixing. It can be ordered in medium ($4.75) or large and served with your typical Vietnamese garnishes. As a disclaimer, I'm no bun rieu connoisseur, but this bowl of noodles was delicious. The tomato-based broth was sour yet balanced. As you can see from my photo, there's no skimping on the crab-shrimp mixture. My only smallest gripe is that the noodles seemed a little too short for my chopsticks to clamp on. Maybe a different rice noodle may do the trick. 

All in all, it was a very tasty bowl of noodle soup that totally satisfied my cravings at a dirt cheap price. Can't ask for much more.
author: Diana C.

description:
Where else can you find a decent bowl of pho for about $6?!

Service is quick, food comes out hot. Divey as H-E-Double-Hockey-Sticks, but one cannot complain given the prices.

One thing to keep in mind though is that their raw beef pho is not thin-sliced, and the egg add-on is a raw egg dropped into your soup.
author: Sam W.

description: Probably the cheapest pho you can get in San Francisco. But I would have to say you get what you payed for like the dirty ambiance and rude service like how the owner who I assume is Loi screams across the restaurant. One of those hole in the wall family owned restaurants in the city. I got their #1 Loi's Special XL which was pretty big for what you pay for. The broth had a strong beef flavor which was a good sign and their portions are very generous. I only would recommend coming here I you would not mind the dirtiness or the bad service. A tip, I would avoid the restroom when coming to Loi's.
author: Peter C.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)
