Loi's attitude however, was completely insulting.  When my friend asked twice for a tea refill, she was ignored by all the waiters.  Thinking they did not hear her or understand, I asked a man walking by in Cantonese since I heard them speaking some Cantonese to each other.  The man walked away and went on to continue talking to his coworkers.  10 minutes later, he walks back with a little kettle of tea, looks into my friend's cup, and yells at us saying in canto that there's still some tea in the cup.  He then continues to insult and talk about us in Vietnamese.  My friend's cup only had a sip of cold tea left ...  Bad service is one thing but loudly insulting customers in the middle of a full restaurant is something else.  Do I recommend Loi's?  For the price, possibly.  Just don't ask for a refill on tea.
author: May T.

description: I've been coming to Loi's for years and I will continue to come here, even though I don't live in San Francisco anymore. My usual is the #1 combination pho. I have to say, it doesn't taste like regular Vietnamese pho at all, but I love it for what it is. The fried egg rolls with fish sauce is pretty good, too. Also, this is one of the cheapest pho places I've ever been to. The only downside, it's small, kind of shabby looking, and the servers aren't always friendly. Also, I'd recommend using a restroom elsewhere. All of which is highly excusable for the quality of food, fast service, and prices!
author: Diana Y.

description:
If you judge this place by the way it looks on the outside (and even inside), you would miss out on pretty good food for the cheap price. 

Although this is your standard Vietnamese food, the thing this restaurant has going is the price. I came here with a friend and ordered two entrees and a starter and the total was under $15. We left feeling full and getting our moneys worth. 

If you decide to use the bathroom here, you have to wiggle your way through the small kitchen. I would recommend using the bathroom before hand.
author: Willie F.

description:
This is the cheapest I've ever seen pho in my entire life. And that's saying a lot, considering most pho restaurants never have anything on the menu over $10. This is also one of the only pho restaurants that has ever offered a 'small' sized bowl and meant it.

When it comes to pho restaurants, I'm a creature of habit. I always get the medium pho with the most variety of beef parts, I always put hoisin but no hot stuff, I always got a glass of ice water, and sometimes when I'm adventurous I get the imperial rolls.

Same story here, except I opted for the larger bowl. This place gets major bonus points for having really cheap prices, and for their order of imperial rolls having been plentiful.

The restaurant is a bit small, though. So there may be a wait if you show up during the lunch or dinner rush.
author: Trish B.

description:
i really hate to bash family-owned businesses, but service here is a joke.

small shop, 8 tables.  having dinner alone tonite, so i ordered the #1 pho.

four kids come in afterwards, sit down, order, and all their dishes arrive quick.
im sitting 4 ft away, and watching them eat.  faaaantastic.
then the lady sets the plate of bean sprouts and basil on my table as if nothing was wrong, like I'm dumb and naive.  she walked by me 6-7 times to deliver all their food and drinks.  inattentive much?
i've never walked out of a restaurant before, and regret not doing so tonite.  but i needed at least more ammo to post on yelp.

the XL pho bowl is cheap, but would be considered a regular size at other shops.  broth was too salty, didn't taste like pho. meat was tough, stringy, and fatty. 

I leave a dollar on the table, then go up to pay. 

lady:  "ok, $5.15."
me:  *hands over $6.00*
lady:  "ok thank u."
me:  O_O

hmmm... keeping my change?

so i just stood at the register.
she goes on bagging takeout orders.
im staring at her snooty face.  
yes, asian ladies can look snooty.
yes, i learned *snooty* from bueller's day off.
this has to be a new low in service.
like she feels rightful ownership of my change.
three guys stood behind me in line.
but I wasn't gonna move.

an eternity later...

lady:  *hands me my change*

I picked my dollar back up, and left the change on the table.
author: Ethan L.

description: im surprised by so many negative reviews. Yes its a little grimmy, but thats part of the charm. I've eaten at about 4 Pho restaurants on Irving alone and this one is by far the best.
author: David D.

description: Love their #1 pho! D Best! The broth is very flavorful and the meat are so yummy and tender! Try their egg roll and BBQ pork it's great too! The price is incredibly low compare to other pho places.
author: Rowen F.

description: Every time my friends come to SF from out of state, as happened last weekend, I take them here for authentic North Vietnamese, Hanoi-style street food. My meat and potatoes are the bbq noodle soups, but when I get a hankering for the Bun Cha Hanoi, nothing else satisfies!
author: Cork G.

description: I highly recommend that you DON'T come here. The service is crappy and the server (short asian dude) is extremely rude. My friend wanted to change her order and the server completely ignored her. He didn't even ask if we wanted any drinks or soda, we were just left with a cup of hot tea. are we supposed to eat greasy food with hot tea?? He even made a scene and yelled at us in front of EVERYONE just because we had "too many napkins out." I mean, why leave out a container full of napkins if you don't want anyone to use it? Talk about CHEAP. It would've been fine if he had just talked to us quietly and politely but he had to make a big deal about it. And even after the ordeal he continued to shout about us to everyone else eating at the other tables. i wouldn't have been surprised if they spit in our food. The silverware and cups were dirty and had dried food stuck to them. The table was sticky and it made me uncomfortable to eat. The food was alright but i was scared that they might've spit in it or something after the whole napkin deal. You could say i'll never come back here ever again. I didn't see all these bad reviews until after i left and felt the need to leave a bad review, in fact i made an account JUST to write this review. But from now on before i walk into a restaurant i've never heard of before, i'll make sure to go on yelp first so that i avoid any more bad experiences just as i did with this restaurant. To save you the trouble, do not eat at this restaurant unless you enjoy dirty silverware and rude asian men.
author: Lauren C.

description: The 36 Health Inspection Review doesnt scare me. I go here twice a week... small pho with beef and chicken, add an cha gio for a buck.
author: boston j.

description: Still cheap (Extra large = $5.95) and improved hygenie rating (from 45 to 82). More reasons to eat there!
author: Jeremy L.

description: The cheapest vietnamese restaurant I've ever encountered! Two bowls of pho (one medium, one x-large), eggrolls (3 big pieces cut in fours), and a coke for only $15 including tax! WHAT A DEAL! I'm definitely going back there again when I'm low on cash!
author: Valerie T.

description: I never knew of this pho restaurant until my friend brought me to it last night. I used to always go to PPQ on 19th and Irving; the one with a cow in the front: http://www.yelp.com/biz/pho-phu-quoc-aka-ppq-restaurant-san-francisco. Not anymore :)! I love hole-in-the-wall restaurants and this is one of them! Their soup base is so tasty and their noodles are perfect! Check out their prices! Where can you get a bowl of pho now-a-days for $4, $5, or even $6?! I heard their menu prices have been the same for years! I also heard their chicken noodle soup is great! The only thing was that the beef slices were kind of chewy.  Check this place out!
author: Jessica C.

description: Cheap and dirty pho...I guess its good cuz its that dirty.
author: Jon W.

description: Yum!  This place is an absolute hole in the wall.  You seriously feel like you are in someone's kitchen.  The people running the place speak very little english.  However, the atmosphere comes across as cozy and nice and the Pho is awesome.  The broth is particularly savory and flavorful.  It almost seems a little thicker than other places broth.  While I was waiting for my soup, someone else's barbecued beef rice plate came out.  It smelled so good!  I will have to try that next time.
author: Kate B.

description: great pho and rice plates... one thing about the pho when you order the meat on the side its all smash up.. kinda different from all the other pho place, my friend said those are the left over meat but taste just as good... no problem here.... hell yeah i would eat here again one thing is the place is small and can only fit so many....
author: JessePanda C.

description:
This tiny Vietnamese restaurant is cheap and good. You can get a huge bowl of Pho for $3.95. That's less than a Mcdonald's value meal. There's no music playing in this restaurant and the menus are thrashed but still readable. The whole time you sit there and eat, you can listen to the conversations of the cook staff.  They talk loud and laugh together..and sometimes sound like they are bitching at each other. Their language is entertainment enough to listen to.  It's cool though..as if you are eating at somebody's home. Sometimes the kids are hanging out in the kitchen. Tight! 
The first time me and Carter ate here...we had so much food on the table and walked out with a bill of $14.52 total. I had a huge plate of rice topped with a quarter roasted chicken topped with 2 freid eggs and soup. Carter had a bowl of beef stew and fried imperial rolls. We couldn't finish the food so we brought it home.  I could practically eat here 2 times a week and probably save just as much as buying groceries...minus the cooking and washing the dishes.  I hope nobody finds out about this place cuz I want it to myself.  I'm just a cheap, frugal Ilocano...it's in the blood.
author: Glenn C.

description: I typically get my pho from Kevin's Noodle House down the street, but after trying Loi's, may have to change my routine. The broth and noodles at Loi's are both far superior. Yummy!
author: Leslie F.

description: Bottomline: you aren't going to get pho any cheaper. Loi still delivers on quality though. You'll have to brave a few flies and some grime, but there's nothing better to cure the common hangover. Be prepared to wait for a table on the weekend mornings.
author: Tom B.

description: Another grubby looking Vietnamese restaurant. The food is pretty good here and I would hate to walk back into the kitchen, because I would probably never eat here again if I did. This would be a place where you're not really here for the service, but for the food. I have had the Bun Rieu here and it is really good, kind of a home style taste. Very yummy broth. My bf says they have the best 5 spice chicken here and he's been coming here since highschool. I would definitely come here again for their food.
author: carebear l.

description:
Why this place sucks.

1. Don't drink the water they give you because it smells like dishwasher soap
2. The MALE owner is incredibly RUDE (not just in the restaurant but in civil society). He once gassed past his stop sign when I clearly had the right of way.
3. Not many people notice so TASTE THE SOUP CAREFULLY. You'll realize they put WAY too much fish sauce in the pho to flavor it. It's that good once you realize it.
4. This place is dirtier than other Chinese places. Sticky tables. Flies everywhere.
author: Resa N.

description: Very good, great prices, fast service. We had the fish ball pho and shrimp and beef bun, spring roll app. The bun was awesome, there were 7 grilled shrimp, and the beef was excellent. The pho was very clean tasting, nut muddy. Total bill was about $18. Walked away super full and satisfied.
author: C B.

description: Best pho joint around in my opinion. Been coming here for years.
author: Warren G.

description:
Loi's is a no-nonsense type  Vietnamese restaurant that may not be right for everyone. Many (myself included) find it to be authentic and positively gritty, while some will be turned off by the invariably blaring TV and the no-nonsense attitude of the staff. 

I think that what some often intepret as rude is just the staff/owner trying to accomodate everyone in what is often a very busy restaurant. I personally find the attitude to be quite warm here.  I have never felt like the owner was annoyed when I asked for more tea/water, etc. He even took it in stride when, after eating, I realized that I didn't have any cash and had to go to the bank once. For me, Loi's beats the other three pho joints between 19th and 25th in terms of flavor, portions and price. 

Recommendations: The green pepper hot sauce on all of the tables makes for a spicily tangy soup that is a refreshing change from Sriracha rooster sauce that spicy Pho lovers often add to their soup. The peppers themselves make nice little appetizers. Of course, Sriracha is also available.

The creamy crab pho is also very nice and hearty. (Look on the wall as I don't think it's in the menu).

Also, the crispy bbq-ed meat dishes give you a generous helping of sweetish meat on the side rather than soggy beef in the soup itself. A plate of bbq meat is easily shared. 

Minuses: Sometimes their Asian basil is less fresh than other pho restaurants, but I haven't noticed an adverse effect on the taste. The place could be cleaner, but then it probably wouldn't be Vietnamese.
author: Douglas S.

description: Okay...so I am very very surprised and shocked about how well my dinner went the night I went to Loi's. My friend had wanted to eat at Loi's and I was apprehensive about going because I had been there once and it was really dirty. I'm the kind of person you see at the  table cleaning the forks, plates, cups..Loi's chairs used to be really sticky and I'd feel like my ass was glued to it...so BINGO. Definitely did not want to go back. I tried to convince my friend not to eat there..but we ended up going and everything was just fine! the table was relatively clean..the utensils were pretty clean..even though I dumped it in tea..the food was REALLY tasty (such a good price!! About 6 dollars for a satisfying plate of BBQ pork, rice, and egg rolls), annnnd I got out of my seat without breaking a sweat! Wow Loi's. Wow.
author: Cris L.

description: I have been coming to this restaurant ever since I was a little kid, so I. I remember here until the wee hours of the morning. Decades ago ... I would eat in the restaurant, but nowadays I mostly get yummy take-out.  I loveeeee their beef pho. Why? Because I love how the pho soaks up all the flavorful broth plus the beef is juicy, nice, tender and is specially ordered, so you won't find it in the market.
author: Jen P.

description: I use to work one block away from here so I would occasionally come here for lunch. Yes, it's a small place and yes, it's durtayy. BUT, I didn't really mind because the prices were cheap, portions are big, and I liked how their rare beef noodle soup tasted. HOWEVER, during my last visit to Loi's, the owner of the restaurant brought over my soup and his whole durtayy thumb was literally submerged in my soup while he was holding it. I watched, in horror, as he placed my pho down and pulled his thumb up out of the soup and pushed the bowl in front of me. I could have asked for a new bowl but deep down inside I knew they'd probably give me the same bowl back and besides, I had already lost my appetite. Got the check and left ASAP. Sorry but I will not be back to Loi's anytime soon, I really didn't need your extra "flavoring" in my pho sir! BTW, the food here is only average! It you must come here, do not order the spring rolls or soy bean milk. trust.
author: A. T.

description: I'm all for family-based restaurants, and Loi's delivers with filling portions at great prices.  Yes, it's dingy and cramped.  Yes, you're never sure if you'll be able to go at a time when there's enough space for your group.  I've never had problems coming here with friends or family, and the staff has always been friendly.  I've tried several of their pho's, vermicelli salads, and a couple of other things.  I appreciate the fresh veggies and intense flavors on their grilled meats.  The pho is made with a strong stock and it doesn't seem like they skimp on any ingredients.  Delicious indeed.  Still, competition is stiff so I wouldn't say it's absolutely the best.  If I lived close by, I'd be a regular for sure.
author: Leneve O.

description: Loi's will get me through this recession.  The food here is super good and super cheap.  And yes, it's a hole in the wall joint and because of that it keeps the prices down.  And on top of that the portions are huge.  You can't complain.  And if you do, you might as well go shoot yourself because you won't be able to find a Vietnamese restaurant with entree items under $5 bucks within the sunset.
author: hello k.

description: I have been a Loi's patron for years. Although this beautiful city is only seven square miles I haven't found a Vietnamese restaurant to top their food. Yummy Yummy Yummy I got love in my Tummy!
author: Alia D.

description: The broth is clean and really great for a small shop. I recommend this authentic vietnamese pho because it is righteous. The price is fair, so I can't find any other reason not to go here.
author: Kevin N.

description:
I'm only giving an extra star because the food was pretty good. I had the North Vietnamese BBQ Pork w/vermicelli noodles #25...It was a ginormous (yay! I get to use the word of the day) plate of food. The beef was in a separate bowl and the vegetables were on it's own plate...be sure to look & choose the leaves closely as some are in their overripe to go stage.  All I can say is that the food is hella cheap...

The BBQ pork was really good, a bit fatty but quite delicious. The Beef / Tripe Pho Noodle Soup was also really nice, not too salty and not overtly oily.

The minuses besides the hole in the ground decor and the flies that seem to nose bomb us once in awhile, was the godawful screaming from the owner. He and another lady were the only ones servicing the tables and let me tell you...he does not understand the use of Indoor Voice! I can't imagine what white people feel like when they have to listen to chinese/vietnamese screaming between the staff, but having to understand their screaming is something else.  I really felt sorry for the workers he was yelling harassments at...
All we ask for was an extra bowl of fish sauce, and the owner barely looked at us and said, "I'm busy...later!"?????WTF??? You don't treat customers like that and expect anything good to come later. Apparently, he's had arrogant issues like this with other customers, just blowing off people's request and giving lame excuses as to "being too busy"...MISTER!! It's called SERVICE for a dang reason! 

If it wasn't for the ladies who even gave us half the attention we as paying people deserve, I'd have chuck my pho at the man for his rudeness.

Okay...enough venting. Be warned of the Pho Nazi...he's actually living on Irving Street and if you like masochistic deviant service..then you found the right spot.

p.s. Be aware that they charge 50 cents for each doggie bag container if you wish to take your leftovers home.
author: Pauline L.

description: I think this place has the most inexpensive pho you'll ever eat. I think it's RIDICULOUS how expensive most pho places are nowadays. Most of the time the portions are pretentious; don't be tricked cuz it's usually the noodles and soup that fills you up. Anyway Loi's is this small, hole-in-the-wall restaurant that is super affordable. It isn't the cleanest looking place but I haven't found any weird crap in my soup yet (phew!) so it's all good. The staff is kinda rude but what do you expect from a place like this. The food is average; pho is pho, every place pretty much tastes the same. The downside is that they don't have bun bo hui (sp?) which sucks cuz it's bomb. Hard to find parking since it's in on Irving. I would recommend if you're running low on cash and want a quick bite. I got a medium size number 1 for about $5 including tip and tax. Thumbs up for a poor college grad like me!!
author: Jenny T.

description:
Horrible service, dirtiest "restaurant" in SF, and even after 9 months I will never set foot in Loi's if it is the last food source on this planet! I still hate this place and advise everyone not to go! Cheap prices are not worth your health and definitely not worth being treated like the dirt they serve you! 

I've heard that quite a few people have gotten sick after eating here... PLEASE report it to the Better Business Bureau otherwise they'll continue serving their filth to innocent customers!
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 

NEVER GOING BACK HERE AGAIN!!!!!!

I would never write a review if I didn't feel so strongly about something, and after eating at Loi's today, it would not be possible to HATE this restaurant more. Hate is a strong word, but that is the feeling that comes to mind after sitting in the dirty little room, that passes for a restaurant, for more than half an hour waiting for my food. My boyfriend and I walked into the restaurant at 2 something in the afternoon expecting some good food and quick service since there were only 5 other people in there. I've been to this restaurant before and respected that it was family owned and ignored how dirty it was because of that. 

But after sitting there for what felt like an eternity waiting for our food to arrive, we noticed the dozens of flies flying around the chopsticks and soup spoons that were just sitting there exposed in the open. The flies would land on the utensils and clean themselves, undoubtedly spreading bacteria and other unthinkable dirtiness. The menus were disgusting as well. And my cup of tea had some snot or something of that composition on there. 

We sat there for THIRTY MINUTES waiting patiently for our simple-to-make Pho ... watching everyone else get their food before us. I told my siblings and they all thought that was strange since they get promptly served every time, and that maybe we did not get served as quickly because we look like little kids.  My siblings also noticed that non-Asian people and older adults get served before younger Asians, like ourselves. How can you run a business based on these principles?!? Does this count as racism? Ageism? Thinking that the money of non-Asians and older people is better than the money of Asians and younger people? Or thinking that we're too stupid to complain or make a point to blast how rude they are?

So after sitting there for thirty whole minutes, the lady comes up to us and doesn't apologize or anything... but JUST asks us what we ordered! As if that wasn't enough, they take another TWENTY MINUTES to finally get our order! Then we had to ask them for the bean sprouts and mint leaves because they apparently forgot about that too! When we finished eating and asked for the check, they just told us the price and didn't even offer a receipt despite them giving receipts to everyone else. They didn't even say thank you. 

I've been to A LOT of restaurants but have never been so highly disrespected and mistreated. Poor service is not their only problem. They also only scored a 42 out of 100 on their health inspection! I would rather be eating out of a trash can than here! My sister even said that she saw the lady that owns the place drop a meatball on the floor... she just picked it up and threw it back into the bowl to serve to a customer even though she knew that my sister saw her!!! Disgusting! Who would want to eat meatballs that have rolled around on that floor?!?

If you don't read everything above, at least read this:
Service was horrible: they wasted an hour of our time (that's a whole $1.50 in quarters for the parking meter!), no apologies, no thank yous, serve certain people first even though we were there first and waiting
Food was raw even with the "boiling" water to cook it, didn't come with everything we expected (no sprouts or mint leaves)
Place with dirty: flies everywhere spreading bacteria, mucus on tea cup, menus were soiled, pick food up from floor to serve to customers, 42/100 on health inspection

Final Rating: Negative One Million. NEVER GOING BACK and HOW DO I GET THIS PLACE SHUT DOWN?!?!
Some of you may have never experienced such horrible service from here, but think about how it would feel if this happened to you because it may (I've been to this restaurant many times before over the years and this has never happened to me until now).
author: Mabel T.

description:
number one, beef on the side, no onions, oh extra lime please
this place might not be the cleanest place on earth but sure serve the excellent pho!
author: Sabrina K.

description: I went to vietnam in january with some friends and it may well have the best food on earth, once i came back to SF a lot of places wouldnt cut it, but Lois is the closest. the best and cheapest northern style vietnamese food in the city.  Best dishes are the tomato crab soup, the 3 kinds of meat noodle soup, and the hanoi style pork and noodles.   Soo good and soo cheap. 2 people will not need to spend more than 15 dollars to fill up.  Please tip generously, i dont know how they stay in business with those prices
author: Jonathan S.

description:
their food is actually pretty good.  i had their bun w/ shrimp and beef. their shrimp was  good.  i really liked it. but if you're planning to come here, i would suggest  ordering take-out. trust me, you dont want to eat here. its kind of dirty  and theres alot of flies. hence their score: 72 or was it 74? still pretty low. and the servers have icky fingernails.  

 WARNING: DO NOT GO TO THEIR BATHROOM!! if you plan on going, do it AFTER you eat!! i've never been but i've heard stories. and other stories. 

but why two stars? cuz i like their food.
author: B B.

description: Food and service always on point, even though its busy! The price is the cheapest in San Francisco. I think its 3.95 for a bowl of Pho. Unheard of. The presentation may not be great, but these people have been in business for a long time and there is a reason! I've been a loyal customer for over 10 years!
author: Mike H.

description:
I had the Bun Cha Ha Noi.  Prices are great, service was fine.  A little small, real hole in the wall.

Highlight was using the restrooms to wash my hands - you have to walk through the kitchen to get there.  Not sure how it passed health inspections.

Only critique, and this was just my mood at the time, the place felt really really tiny, and I felt somewhat rushed as it was dinner time and I was occupying a table for 4 (I was alone).  They might want to put in some tables for 2.  But that's just me finding something to nit-pick.

Would definitely go there again - would like to try their Ban Cuon.
author: That's For N.

description: Perfectly unassuming, Loi's is sublime. The decor is forgettable and the atmosphere punctuated by the perpetual sounds of broadcast TV. Hip, Loi's isn't :). So, take a seat at one of the sticky tables and try a generous plate of BBQ pork and rice. Your satisfaction is guaranteed for less than five dollars, but don't count your calories.
author: David D.

description: Looking for a good Mom&Pop pho shop ... then this is the place to go.  Love the pho, bun, pork chops, and the specials that are not listed on the menu .... raw beef salad!
author: Mrs L.

description: Its the best bang for its buck. The Vietnamese food here is the most affordable you can get.
author: Jack L.

description: their food is ok but their service sucks!!! the owner were treating us badly and always have that angry look!!! just because i ask him nicely can i have cooked beansprout!!! for the freaking PHO? i never been to a vietnamese restaurant treat their coustomer so badly and i been there 3times and he treat us the same!!!
author: Scott Z.

description: Yum!! This place is your usual hole in the wall, where the cleanliness & service are suspect.  However, the food is GREAT!  The bbq meats are their specialties, so its worth a try.  Their pho soup broth is really flavorful too.  Try the beef stew w/ rice or noodles.   If you want healthy food, this is not a place to go, but its a damn good place to go!
author: Amelia S.

description: The place is a bit run down and a little on the dirty side, but the food is CHEAP and good. You can get a large bowl of pho for less than $5!! Where else can you get that in the city?? I ordered a medium bowl of rice noodles..and with tax it came up to $4.30. The noodles taste yummy, and the chef packs tons of extras with it. You'll get a good bang for your buck at Loi's.
author: Cee J.

description: I've always liked coming to Loi's even before all the influx of newer Pho restaurants.  They to me are always high quality and their Pho is unique because they seem to give different parts of meat than most other places.  Their beef seems thicker.  Not a bad thing.  I haven't been here in a while so not sure if that is still the case but their broth is always pretty good and the prices are right.
author: Mark W.

description: I was going to go with three stars, however I think three would imply that I would go back.  I won't.  It wasn't the worst meal I've had, however I left unsatisfied.  We tried the vietnamese eggrolls as well as the pork skin rolls.   Both were not tasty what-so-ever.  The porkskin ones were dry and tasteless.  We split the BBQ porkchop and BBQ chicken pho.  The broth was good, a little salty but good, however the meat was a little dodgy.  The pork was thick cut and not quite cooked all the way through, and then the chicken thigh/leg was dry.  Oh well....it seems like they are doing well...it is cheap.
author: Brye L.

description: Yummy pho!! I'm not a big fan of pho but now I've changed my mind. I will eat pho at Loi's  :D
author: Maria H.

description: Dirty hole in the wall. But what can I say? Cheap, fast, big portions and tastes good. Be warned that there's a distinctive smell from their broth that some people can't stand - use the basil and lime generously. The cheap price probably comes from the low quality beef they use. From time to time they really mess up on the noodles, either too raw or too cooked. ugh.
author: Gary L.

description: Argh.. I'm going to keep this short.  Food was ALRIGHT.   I ordered Bun Bo Nuong with the Bun on the side, extra veggies.  It was a weird request, but I'm on a diet, so I can't slurge on the noodles.  So after I ordered, he brought me tea, then my food.  I was sitting a bit waiting for the check which didn't come so I took the liberty of going to the front and paying.  I was waiting there and as he finished counting out change, I noticed him punching some numbers in the cash register.  The total read $6.05, I waited.. he didn't say one word nor did he look up at me.  I then asked, is that my total?  He nodded without looking at me.  I then gave him my $10 bill, and he gave me my change... without looking at me, or thanking me.  Or even grunting.    I seriously wanted to cuss him out for being such a pisser, but I decided against it.  BTW I left without tipping anything, I should've spit on the money before I gave it to the guy.    Argh...
author: Alice E.

description:
So i will never forget the first time i came here.. It was my first week moving to SF and my roommates decided to take me here after telling them i wanted vietnamese bun. We pulled up, parked and walked in. 2 seconds later i walked right out! If you've been here, you know what im talking about. It's a tiny place with about 25 people filled in there with a capacity of im assuming 16. No.. that isn't the reason i walked out, i seriously thought this place was a joke and my roommates were messing with me. One look and i was afraid to go back in. This place is def. your old school ma and pa vietnamese restaurant that has not been remodeled or updated since who knows when. We got seated by im assuming the owner, a man that always wears a navy blue vest =) He takes our order without even giving us a minute to look at the menu, but luckly my roommates have been here too many times and knew what to order me.

My food came out and i was surprise. I got the bbq pork bun (dry noodles) and was amazed at the presentation. It's neatly and nicely packed with a small bowl of fish sauce. I figured the place is known for their food not the look of the place. You might get that icky feeling just dont look around! Eat with one hand covering your eyes and your fine! What do you expect it's a hole in the wall joint! Besides the place the service was fast and this place always seems to have a wait outside. Don't get offended if the man takes your plate/bowl away or in my case cleans the table and throws everything in your bowl right after your done  in front of you. He's just trying to hustle and get people in and out. My roommates and I always try to pay and walk out before getting grossed out to his speedy cleaning routine.

I've been back ever since and i usually stick to the bun or the crab noodle soup and order togo. The price is by far the cheapest i've had for vietnamese food and you actually get a lot for the price.
author: Jacinta D.

description: Good pho at a great price!  I really liked the BBQ pork dish, large portions with a big mound of rice.  Not a great atmosphere, but for the price, you get what you pay for.  Would recommend anyone that wants a quick lunch or dinner with no frills.
author: David P.

description: Came here a few weeks ago with my folks and the bf.  For the prices of everything here, it's cool.  But after we left, my bf and I both had a horrible stomach ache.
author: Selene K.

description: I've been eating here since they opened about 20 yrs ago... The food is good... The Vietnamese rolls are probably the best on Irving... The rare beef Pho noodle soup is my favorite but I love the BBQ pork too. Great prices... but I don't come here very often anymore because it is kind of dirty... I rinse my fork in the hot tea that comes in a plastic glass... I'm afraid to use the plastic chopsticks... I do order large quantities of the rolls to take out for parties.
author: jane f.

description: I've been going to this place since I was a kid. Anyway, I always go there for the fried eggrolls and the bbq beef pho!! MmMMmmmM! I haven't been to a pho place where they put bbq meat and pho together. VERY VERY good for cold and rainy days like today. The owner is pretty friendly as well but I'm not sure about how much english he knows because I usually order in canto. Gonna go back there for suuuureeee!^^
author: Shu L.

description:
loi's is a great place to go if you are looking for good authentic vietnamese food.  i have been eating here for several years & the food is still good.  

i typically get the bbq pork chop & shrimp w/ egg over rice, a order of fried egg rolls or imperial rolls to go with my meal.  my wife orders, the pho.  the food is always hot & good.  you get alot of food for the small sum of money spent.  

the two guys are hilarious, they treat you well & always make sure that you are well fed.  the place is small hole in the wall & is often crowded so you may have to wait for a table but the food is worth it.  parking is kinda tough in this neighborhood but i live near by so its not a problem for me.   if you plan on going make sure its not on a wendsday as they are closed.
author: larry s.

description: Not the best Pho by a longshot, but better than most I've eaten lately.  The spring rolls are ok, even though the rice paper seemed a bit too thick.  Service was prompt and friendly, and the prices can't be beat.  Here's hoping that the new vietnamese spot that is taking over where Spanish Fly used to be is great.  This city needs good pho in a neighborhood other that the 'loin.
author: Benjamin P.

description: Best bun thit nuong cha gio outside of Tu Lan. Best pho on Irving.  Super cheap, super fast, if somewhat brusque.  But for a quick, filling, delicious, cheap meal without any frills, this place satisfies.
author: VFSeamonkey M.

description: Loi's is seriously the bomb. I have become addicted to this place's yummy-ass bbq beef plates (and their pork chops). My mouth waters when I walk up to the door. The prices can't be beat. Three of us ate here (with beer) for under 30 bucks.
author: Zoeboe D.

description:
bbq pork noodle soup was terrific!

if only they would refill my water without me having to yell as they zoomed past my table
author: April T.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy.  If you're in the mood for some tasty pho and are lacking cash, look no further.  You can get a dee-lish meal for cheaper than what you could cook it for at home!  The vermicelli Bun dishes are fab, as are the noodle soups.  The BBQ beef is to die for.  

One star dinged down from a five star for having a poor dining atmosphere in the restaurant.  We always get take-out.  Dining in the restaurant definitely lessens the appeal of the food!
author: amy b.

description: Best vietnamese food.  I used to live in the Bay Area and make trips to this place just to get a good fix of vietnamese food.  Now I live in Ohio and I still try and make it back here whenever I am in town.  The Pho is great; flavorful broth, excellent meat, and wonderful tendon.  Their imperial rolls are great to, not small and crammed with meat, noodles and spices.  All of that said some I know find it too dirty.  The restroom is through the kitchen where you can see a mountain of imperial rolls and 3 asian women cooking furiously. Obviously it is my vote to not let the dirt stop you from enjoying their wonderful food.
author: Brian B.

description: Yes Please!  #16, super tasty and cheap...out the door in a flash...wammy!  Love Loi's!
author: Dominic P.

description: This review is only about the BBQ combo plates.  Oh so delish....My husband is addicted to the BBQ pork chop & chicken over rice and I love the BBQ chicken and shrimp over rice( not an option on the menu but they indulge me).  The BBQ is always finger licking good, the spices they use infuse the meat with a wonderful aroma (chinese five spice?)  whatever it is it's yummy.  And, the pork, chicken, & shrimp are cooked just right.  For instance, the chicken is moist not dry and the shrimp are juicy but blackened.  Perfection.  Cheap honest food.
author: jennifer a.

description: This place is literally a hole in the wall. It is so small yet it gets packed during lunch and dinner. My boyfriend was the one loves this place, so we come here almost on a weekly basis. Pho here is cheap! $4 for a medium size(its actually a small) and a bowl of extra large is $6.Service is so-so. You cannot really expect too much of service from here.Overall food is great!
author: Joanne H.

description: I am always searching for the most succulent and wondrous of grilled pork over vietnamese rice noodles.  The so-called "bun" noodle dish. With chopped lettuce and cucumbers and carrot.  Loi's is fantastic.  #25 is a special Northern Vietnamese version with tons of greens and gravy and also meatballs.  Seating is at picnic tables.  A hole in the wall treasure.
author: Kwai Chang C.

description: OK-I have been coming here since the 90's its a true hole in the wall and they have the same menu/prices for as long as ive been going...BUT,anyone who knows PHO and has a clue to whats good quality and whats not-their PHO is pretty lame.The broth can be like dirty dishwater.I mean,its not horrible but it always has a weird,almost dirty taste(its not the cleanest restuarant for sure).But for 3.95 Im willing to take it when Im on a low budget which these days is often.Kevins noodle house near 19th across from PPQ is WAY better for about a buck or 2 more.
author: james m.

description:
hella good and hella cheap! 

the bun cha ha noi was really yummy. i hear the pho is pretty good too. =)
author: Linda N.

description: I like the way they do the bbq plate and pho noodles bowl.  It good to have just the chicken stock pho once in a while without having all that tasteless little pieces of white chicken meat.  I'd rather have stock and noodles with a bbq pork plate on the side. very homemade type food.
author: Stevezee C.

description: Great food at a great price! I just wished the restaurant was a little bit bigger. Somehow everything always feels sticky there, but I still love the food! terrific family owned vietnamese restaurant!
author: Vivian D.

description: hahaha Loi's, first advice don't use the bathroom my friend went in and described it for me and it wasn't a pretty sight. Definitely a hole in the wall, yes it feels crazy dirty but their pho is pretty freaking awesome and hella cheap. it's like 5 or 6 bucks for a large bowl of pho. The soup is nice and hot and full of flavor, the meat is very tender and the cilantro is awesome. If you're scared of dirty places dont go here if you're not and you want to get some good pho try it out.
author: Preston L.

description: I had a great bowl of pork and pork skin bun tonight for about $6, with tax.  Good portion, tasty pork, could've used some more mint though.  Friendly service and it took under 5 minutes for me to get my food.  Props for the blaring Chinese soap opera on the TV as well, really set the mood.
author: Jake S.

description: The secret to Loi's good broth is when they bring over your soup with their dirty thumb inside. Nevertheless, still 5 stars! Yay!
author: Sandy F.

description:
you know how they say the dirtier the better food. definitely applies to loi's. when i walk in i already feel pretty gross. the menus are all old and dirty, and that's not a good sign. i like going to clean places.

but the reason why i go to loi's cause it's so good. i love how they don't give slices of meat, but just a huge portion of ground meat. i'm definitely a special combo person, and they make it right. 

even though it's so dirty, i love their pho. and it's cheap.
author: Natalie B.

description: Definitely a hole-in-the-wall restaurant. Prices are good. Food is tasty though may not be the freshest nor of the highest quality ingredient-wise. I had a BBQ chicken and beef rice plate. My chicken almost tasted like it was leftover from the night before and microwaved, as it was tough. If I come back it'll be to try the pho as others seem to like it, but from my experience the quality of the food here is not great. Anyone giving this 5 stars is nuts. I'll have to give it 2 stars to offset the others.
author: Dijon Y.

description: I come here atleast once a week! Best Pho on Irving and the cheapest around - what more could you ask for?
author: Michael T.

description: I've been here a couple of times before I found an ant in my pho. Needless to say...I do not come here anymore...
author: Anna Z.

description: honestly i dont come to this place as often as before anymore because its kidda far from my house but i have to say every single time i pass by this area i always stop and get something to eat from here. the 'bun cha ha noi' and the crap nooodle is my favorite :D . the restaurant is very small and old looking but the foods are always delicious.
author: Phuong N.

description:
It's cheap!

I think the small crab meat tomato pho is only $3.75 and small beef stew is only $3.50!
author: N F.

description: I drive all the way from Oakland to hit this spot up! No place like Loi's. I just recently started eating meat again, so the BBQ beef with rice is the hit. I always order the same thing, but my homies has ordered the Pho' and they say you can't go wrong.  The food is inexpensive,  especially wit the big portions.  You get complimentary hot tea and the seating is cool with their big tables (I hate being squished at these dinky tables at other places).  The only thing is you need to be prepared wit the CASH only! One last cool thang -- Tutti Melon is down the block for dessert.
author: liza g.

description: We have come here many times over the last 10 years. It's nothing fancy, but the food is always good,hot, and plentiful. The restaurant is small--even a bit cramped. It's not the cleanest looking restaurant, but we have never had a bad experience regarding the food. Oh yeah, the prices are very reasonable.
author: Joe M.

description:
rekindled...

i have not been to this place since my high school haircut days on Irving street. a friend told me about this Pho place called Loi's, right when i went in i remembered this place umm 7 years ago.. 

anyways great pho special Loi's style. Yes they got it real real dirty with the thumb in the broth and the waiter and waitress cleaning while your sitting at the table.. but through the cleanliness and little wait.. its serve spectacular Pho and others things.. what we had was the Loi Special Pho and Bun (with shrimp n pork).. very filling and very tasty.. i cant believe i frogot how cheap it was..

it makes you think .. all the other Pho establishments are making a killing charing you $8.00 for freaking PHO!!!.. (ahem.. ppq!!)

so anyways next time i am going to try the five spice chicken and some other exciting things..

FYI.. some annoying couple SWWOOPED on a family of four (with 2 small kids) and did not have the decency to let the family sit first.. if it was me i would have thrown tea on them...
author: Jon N.

description: typical asian noodle house--so don't expect to be waited on. excellent food for excellent prices. i would totally come here everyday. my sister and i both ate for under $7 (but I just had noodle soup with no meat).
author: Jessica S.

description: This is an outrage. How dare this place still get good ratings. People with taste buds. Join the revolution to lower this places' rating. It is s gross. I would give it 0 stars if I could. This places angers me because it gets good ratings when its even below par. HATE!!!
author: Chris L.

description: A great hole in the wall experience.  I've been here many many times, food is delicious, price is even better, parking is difficult most hours of the day, but totally worth it.
author: Erika C.

description: I come here for the BBQ pork and beef with an emperor roll plate and damn its good. Its a lot of food and freakin delicious and with a cold beer you'll only be paying less than ten bucks.
author: xxalex k.

description:
A friend's recommendation had pulled me to Loi's on a Thursday evening. I was hoping to find a good bowl of pho and other Vietnamese dishes in the city. I'm very sad to say that my search continues. 

Loi's was quite possibly the worst Vietnamese food I've ever had in my life. When other reviewers say it tasted like a foot would have tasted, they honestly mean it. No exaggeration, no humor, no nonsense. They aren't trying to make a joke, the fact is the food was not good. I don't believe the chef has any sense of "gia vi" (vietnamese for spices, flavors) whatsoever. What my bowl of pho lacked in traditional flavors and aromas it made up for with salt (maybe it wasn't even nuoc mam), tap water, salt, poor cuts of meat, oh and did I mention salt? The raw meat that goes in your pho was not right...it wasn't quite ground beef but it was close. 

I'm being very critical with my review here but it is honestly how I feel about how poor a choice this place was for a bowl of pho. At least the people were friendly and made sure I was enjoying my meal (I forced a smile and lied to the lady that it was good...I don't like to hurt feelings). The place was not that dirty, it was just what you can expect from a pho place in a major city. The family owned environment was nice and I support that, I just don't support the lack of quality.
author: Brandon V.

description: fresh, small, cheap, amazing! the bbq pork pho is a must.
author: Esperanza A.

description: My family and I have become regulars at Loi's for the convenience of affordable prices, variety and the most tastiest pho broth I ever tried in the city. For an XL #1 pho duc biet a cover charge of $6.75 where if you went down the street to PPQ possibly an 8-9 dollar charge, and less savory. I always order the combo #1, never dissapoints. Possible cons to the place however, are the ghetto bathrooms found pass the kitchen and less contemporary decor of the place. But the taste and service of Loi's is unbeatable, so 5 stars to Loi's! Hip hip hooray ;D
author: Fat C.

description:
wow, loi's is awesome good. total gem in the sunset.
it's a hole in the wall, but they serve up some damn good pho.
medium is their smallest bowl and it's so huge and so affordable.
$3.75!! can't beat that!

but i think their best entree is the BBQ meats with pho. a bit more pricey but definitely worth it.

all i gotta say, is DAMN GOOD.
author: Heidi L.

description: Love the 5 spice BBQ chicken here. I eat it over the cold vermicelli noodles. It's a huge portion and it's super cheap! Minus 1 star for cleanliness. I found an ant on my noodle (before eating) and the take out box the woman gave me to pack up my leftovers was dirty. I'll still come back though.
author: Al T.

description: best pho for the price probably better than some places that charge more. yeah the place is small and dirty. sometimes there is a wait because of limited seating. of course the service sucks, 90% of pho restaurant service suck but the food and price makes up for it.
author: Meuy X.

description: This is my favorite place to eat.  I've been going there for 20 years.  Yeah, it's dirty but I got used to it.  Where else can you feed the entire family for less than twenty bucks.   Probably the best pho' in town.  Quality and value under one roof.  Very rare!!  My favorite is C2, BBQ Beef and BBQ shrimp with noodle soup.
author: Nicholas W.

description: Omgosh its so good. like seriously. i love how it smells right when they bring the food out :]] hahah, anyways yeah it's pretty small buttttt greatgreatgreatt!
author: Erica A.

description: Really good pho. The beef kinda had a weird smell... but it's pho, what the hey, I'll eat it. And only five bucks for a large? WHAT A STEAL. My friend had the Grilled pork over vermicelli with a egg roll. Only six dollars? WHAT A STEAL. It was actually pretty good. The people were nice. It was pretty dirty. Minus one star.
author: Katherine C.

description: Hands down the best Pho around. I can't go anywhere else. And it's nice and cheap! I love it.
author: Anita K.

description:
this place is crap! the food was OK and there was a piece of hair in my PORK! the bowl used for the pho was dirty and old and so were the tables and chairs.

i dont ever plan on coming here again and never even thinking about it!
author: Kenny L.

description: The food here is awesome!  I had the BBQ Pork over rice.  As soon as it came to the table the smell of it had me very excited.  My girlfriend who loves Pho Ga more than anyone should was impressed with the quality and quantity of it for the price.  Those two dishes and shrimp rolls cost us a whopping $13.75
author: Matt P.

description:
I tried Loi's for the first time this week and it was ok. 
1 star for the food being pretty tasty and another for the friendly service. I walked in and the place was full of people, I thought to myself, "this is a good sign!" We got seated and then the waiter never left, he just stood by our table waiting for us to order. I don't know about you, but I like to peruse the menu and consider my options and maybe ask what other people in my party are thinking about ordering. But that's just me. So, he ordered beef pho and I ordered ah I forgot the name but it was BBQ beef over noodles with veggies plus an order of egg rolls for both of us. We got the food and it was ok. My friend asked the waiter for some basil because he didn't get a plate with bean sprouts and basil that I thought usually comes with pho but nonetheless the waiter came back and gave my friend a handful of basil. I thought it was a little  strange/unsanitary  that he didn't put it on a plate. All in all it wasn't horrible and it wasn't amazing. It was really cheap, really fast and really dirty. If that's ok with you then I would recommend this place otherwise go to turtle tower!
author: Nicole E.

description:
DOUCHE BAG OWNER/WAITER!!!

he was such an a**hole!!! 
right when we sat down, before we had menus in hand, he was waiting there impatiently wanting to take our  order.  When we had decided my mom said "bbq pork over rice noodles," sister said "number 9," and i said  
"D" (because it was chicken pho). Anyways when we got our food, they had given my mom bbq beef over rice noodles, when she had ordered bbq pork. So we asked, and we thought he'd be like "okay sorry, i'll get your correct order." NOPE, he gave us SO MUCH attitude, yelling "you ordered number 16!!!" "number 16!!!" and my mom nicely said "i wanted the bbq pork" and he kept insisting my mom had ordered number 16, when she had never said anything about number 16! he then finally took the bowl, and came back immediately yelling "state clearly what you want, soup noodles? rice?? you need to tell me exactly what you want" SOOO rude, i dont think i've ever been treated like that in a restaurant before.  Finally we got the right order, and we ate. My sister had left overs so we asked for a box. The same douche said in a extremely rude voice "it COSTS Money!!" tell me why he couldnt have just said "oh boxes cost 50 cents, is that okay?" GEEZ! people are ridiculous!  
I mean there was nothing i could really do except leave no tip. I feel kind of bad because the other waitress/bus lady was nice and knew he was being a complete jerk. but that guy can kiss my butt!
author: Jennifer M.

description: Loi's is one of my favorite places to get cheap and delicious vietnamese food. Its pretty small inside, and not as cleanly as you would like but the food is still good. Their menu is not that large but with all the basics. I usually get the bbq beef and eggrolls over rice or vermicelli noodles. I like their beef because its not all fatty or boney. Costs about 6.50 a plate. Their Pho is pretty good as well. If your looking for a cheap place to eat and dont mind the actual look of the restaurant than this is the place!
author: Angela C.

description: i've been here over a handful of times and the food is always great. the service isnt 5 stars but i come here to EAT and not be pampered. i recommend the beef and chicken soup combo and the bbq grilled pork over rice. yumm.
author: Michelle R.

description: small hole in the wall that offers northern Vietnamese cuisine, don't let the oily menus and wet utensils scare you off :), number 25 and 10 are super tasty.  it can be a bit cumbersome for parties of 4 or more but the affordability of their plates makes up for cramped seating and wiping down your chopsticks and spoons. they take plastic as well , a rarity for any food joint on Irving...go .. go now.
author: Wei W.

And when the bill came, they charged us only $3.50 per bowl (it seemed like the receipts were right--I don't think they gave us someone else's receipt). So the meal was only $15 after tax and tip!!! I would definitely come here over PPQ and Kevin's noodle house.

UPDATE:
Had a really bad experience at Lois that transformed my 4 start to a 2 star. In the past I could see past the shortcomings of this place because the food was consistently good, especially for the price. I've had stuff floating in my water, pieces of plastic bag in my beef stew noodle, but didn't fret. A few months back, we were wrapping up our meal and asked the shorter waiter/owner (with the funny cap) to get a box to go. For some reason he snaps at us and says "If you want a box you got to pay 50 cents!" Whoa. Okay. Where the hell did that come from? I understand that the city made you buy these new types of containers, but you don't have to take it out on your customers, especially ones that have been going there for 15+ years. Anyhow, I was displeased to say the least and that outburst was really uncalled for. Why not just raise your prices to help with the cost? Because of that incident,  I have vowed to never step foot there again. Do take out orders count?

description:
Four things I look for in a pho place.. cheap, filling, fresh, good broth.  Loi's meets them all.
This is easily one of the last good pho places in the Bay Area.  The prices of their food are still set at the 1999 level.  Easily affordable by all, including me.  A large order of pho is more than many can finish in one sitting and their XL will fill even me up.  They are not one of those modern pho places that give you a huge bucket like bowl but only fill it half full, their pho is filled to the rim with a good amount of noodles and meat.  Bean sprouts and basil are always fresh (the 3 times I was there at least).  and their broth, although like any Asian restaurant, is filled with MSG. It actually tastes like decent beef broth, exactly how pho broth should taste.
Pho used to be my default food if I had to eat out, but recently, Bay Area pho joints have gone downhill.  Prices skyrocketed to an average of 6.95 for a large (often the only thing large about these is the unfilled space in the bowl) and 5.95 for mediam.  Portions has gone down (both meat and noodles, you can grasp all the noodles most pho place give you in your chopsticks pretty easily nowdays) and many start to cut corners on the broth.  In an age where i almost  no longer believed honest Vietnamese food still existed, my faith  was restored once I found Loi's.
